title: peoples vote march live updates brexit referendum eu deal westminster london latest
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsSadiq&nbspKhan says another referendum is needed because young people's 'future is on the line'Click to followIndy PoliticsAn estimated 700,000 people have gathered in central London to call for a second referendum on a final Brexit&nbspdeal.&nbspMPs&nbspfrom across the political spectrum and a slew of famous names took part in the People's Vote march, sponsored by The Independent&nbspas part of its Final Say campaign.Some 1,000 young activists led&nbspthe so-called march for the future&nbspfrom Park Lane towards a rally in Parliament Square.There, demonstrators heard speeches from&nbsphousehold names including television presenter Delia Smith and London mayor Sadiq Khan.Organisers&nbspestimate some 700,000 have turned outYoung people&nbsp'forsaken'&nbspby the older generation, anti-Brexit campaigners&nbspclaimMore than 946,000 people have now signed The Independent's petition calling for a the public to be given a&nbspFinal Say on the Brexit deal.Thousands of signatures have flooded in today amid a huge turnout for the People's Vote march.Addressing the rally this afternoon,&nbspThe Independent's editor Christian Broughton said he had hoped we might get as many as 20,000&nbspsignatures when the petition launched earlier this year.Conservative MP Sarah Wollaston said calls for a People's Vote can no longer be ignored following today's protest, urging Jeremy Corbyn to back a second referendum.&nbspThe Totnes MP, who took part in the march, said a second referendum could result in another Leave vote but we need to be given the chance to see it.She added: Let people weigh up and the pros and cons of the actual deal or no deal that we're heading for and then they can give their informed consent, and for me that's the key principle here.Ms Wollaston said the backing of Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn would absolutely make a difference to calls for a second referendum, adding: If we had the whole of the Labour party, as well as the SNP, the Liberal Demcorats, and obviously a very significant number of my colleagues, we would get it past it.We need him&nbspto come behind it.Nigel Farage, who has been at a Leave Means Leave rally in Harrogate today, said he would be happy to have another referendum in 20 years or so.&nbspSpeaking to Sky News, the former Ukip leader suggested holding a&nbspnew vote in the near future&nbspwould cause a wave of public anger and plunge the country into more uncertainty.He claimed the UK would vote to leave the EU by a much bigger margin in a second referendum.Vince&nbspCable, leader of the Liberal Democrats, said he thinks people have woken up to the potential disaster of Brexit.He added: Even if they negotiate a deal, it's going to be a bad deal, where we're going to spend years under European Union rules but have no say in them and beyond that there's a cliff edge.We've realised there isn't a good deal coming out of this and a lot of people are frightened, people are worried.Addressing the rally earlier, he said it was the majority of his generation that voted to leave, taking the freedom away from young voters.To cheers from the crowds, he added: There is no deal better than the one we have now: it is better for Britain and better for Europe.&nbspConservative MP Anna&nbspSoubry&nbsptold the thousands gathered in Parliament Square that it is clear we are the many.Addressing the cheering crowd, she added: We are winning the argument, most importantly against those who voted leave.We will take responsibly and sort out this mess.Labour MP Chuka Umunna, whose Lambeth constituency had the highest percentage of Remain voters in England, hit&nbspout at arch Brexiteers who have tried to smear us as some liberal metropolitan elite, when nothing could be further from the truth.&nbspHe told the crowd:&nbspRight from the start of this debate they tried to set different parts of our United Kingdom against each other they wanted to ide this country. And the truth is, whether you are from a Remain or Leave area, the problems are the same.&nbspWhether you are from Liverpool, Lincoln, Llanduno, Livingston in Scotland or Lambeth, where I am, Brexit is not going to make those problems better, it is going to make them worse.The deal on the table is nowhere near as good as the deal we've got now.Green Party MP Caroline Lucas described the huge crowd was a beautiful sight.She told those gathered:What a movement we have become.The Green Party is proud to be part of this amazing movement for a People's Vote, because we know that democracy didn't end on the 23rd June 2016.That referendum wasn't the end of the story it was the start of something new.&nbspShe said Brexit would make our poorest communities even poorer and more powerless.We must have that People's Vote, but we must also re-programme an economy that fails so many, that is based on such inequality, that condemns us to climate breakdown.You can watch The Independent editor&nbspChristian Broughton's speech here:The Independent's editor Christian Broughton has addressed the crowd gathered in Parliament Square. He said:&nbspTheresa May says that the Final Say referendum will be a politicians' vote, not a people's vote, but we can all remember what some politicians&nbsptold us in 2016.&nbspWe, the people, can all now see what's really coming. And&nbspfrom where I'm standing it looks like a People's Vote to me.When we started the Final Say campaign in July, our politics team&nbsphoped we might get as many as 20,000&nbspsignatures on our change.org petition.&nbspWell, this morning I checked: we had&nbsp940,000 signatures. And I'm pretty sure that by the end of today there'll be a few more.&nbspWe have to keep on showing up and signing up.&nbspOnly The Independent&nbspcould start this campaign because it's not tied to any political party.&nbspWe trust our readers,&nbspwe&nbsptrust our reporters and we tell it honestly as it is.Mr Broughton then introduced politicians from across the political spectrum, including&nbspCaroline Lucas, Chuka&nbspUmunna, and Vince Cable.Actor Andy Serkis is marching alongside thousands in central London, with his 14-year-old son Louis and wife Lorraine Ashbourne.The Lord Of The Rings actor said he is supporting the protest as he believes there should be a second referendum “now that people are more informed”.&nbspThe 54-year-old said: “The will of the people doesn't have to stand still, it's not an immovable thing that is fixed.&nbsp“The will of the people is now, it's people expressing their points of view in a more informed state.”&nbspMr Serkis also expressed concern for the film industry if the UK were to leave the EU.&nbspHe said: “There's free movement between the European countries and we've attracted a lot of industry here as a result and that could be seriously damaged, which is the same for a lot of industries.”&nbspPABrexit must not be allowed to undermine workers' rights, says Jeremy Corbyn&nbspAs crowds rallied in London&nbspto demand a vote on the EU referendum, Jeremy Corbyn told United Nations chiefs in Geneva Brexit must not be allowed to undermine workers' rights.The Labour leader said he would work with other countries to resist attempts to reduce protections for UK staff.Mr Corbyn was in the Swiss city to meet Michelle Bachelet, UN high commissioner for human rights, and Guy Ryder, director-general of the International Labour Organisation.He said: Britain is leaving the EU, but we must and will work together with those in other countries to resist the pressure to undermine rights and protections at work.Tax dodging, speculation and unaccountable corporate power have created economic inequality on a vast scale and sucked wealth and jobs out of community after community.Average pay in Britain is now lower than a decade ago and workers have faced a concerted attack on their rights under this Tory Government.We are determined to secure stronger rights at work and fair rules for business as we leave the EU as part of a new economic settlement which delivers for the many, not the few.PASadiq Kahn addresses&nbspthe crowd&nbspin Parliament Square&nbspLondon mayor Sadiq Khan has said there should be another referendum because young people's future is on the line.&nbspWhat a day, what a turnout, he told the crowd gathered in Parliament Square,&nbspdescribing the event as an historic moment.&nbspIt was absolutely right that it was young people&nbspleading this march because it's their future that's on the line, he said.&nbspYoung people's voices wasn't heard during the EU referendum campaign, but their voices are being heard loud and clear today.&nbspThe government doesn't have a mandate to gamble with our future. Are we going to stand by and let them?&nbspHe was met with shouts of,&nbspNo.&nbspTelevision personality and chef Delia Smith told the crowd: I'm so afraid of what's happening to our beloved country and the people making grave decisions on our behalf.&nbspWhen the vote happened, we were not fully informed. Now we know: dire consequences. That can be summed up in two words: Unmitigated chaos.&nbsp&nbspThe counter protest in Harrogate is underway where the audience is hearing&nbspfrom speakers including former Ukip leader Nigel Farage,&nbspleader of Bro-Brexit campaign group Leave Means Leave, Richard Tice, and Labour MP Kate Hooey.&nbspMs Hooey said “Our country should always come above our party.&nbsp“We shouldn't really be here. We had a clear vote to leave, we know that people knew what they were voting for, even though we are being told people were stupid and racist.“It is not a question about leave or remain, it is a question of being democratic, or anti-democratic.“I get very angry when I see the London elite making their views as if they know what is going on in the rest of the country. title: Brexit news Emmanuel Macron french visa UK citizen theresa may leave eu
story: Mr Macron had meant to say UK citizens would not need visas if they wanted to travel to France during&nbspa press briefing in which he was speaking in English.Instead of saying, &ldquowe will not start visas, he said:&nbsp&ldquoWe will not stop visas.The mix-up came after the BBC&rsquos Gavin Lee asked President Macron whether newspaper reports of UK nationals needing visas for work or holidays in the event of a no-deal Brexit were true.The president's response was that &ldquowe will not stop visas, it is fake news, as some other leaders would say, and he went on to say &ldquowe will definitely deliver visas for people.                Merkel and Macron CAVE IN and demand EU make CONCESSIONS to UK                Macron: Parliament passes plan for &pound1,300 tax break to home a refugeeMr Macron&rsquos aides said his intentional comments had been lost in translation as they put the blunder down to a &ldquosecond language slip-up.The aides reiterated Mr Macron had intended to say &ldquowe will not start visas for British people.UK citizens currently enjoy visa-free travel in the EU - but that could change with Brexit.The UK is due to leave the European Union on March 29, 2019.Macron made an embarrassing mistake  (Image: )French President Emmanuel Macron talking to media at the end of an EU chief of state summit (Image: )A deal with the 28-nation bloc remains elusive as Mrs May failed this week to convince EU leaders she had come up with any fresh proposals during so-called &ldquocrunch talks in Brussels.The discussions this week were supposed to produce the first signs of a deal between the UK and the EU.But the bloc accused the Prime Minister of failing to come up with anything new, as the threat of a no-deal Brexit looms.In response, German leader Angela Merkel has urged European Union members to make preparations for a no-deal outcome after the talks failed to produce a breakthrough. title: royal wedding princess eugenie wedding soap opera
story: Too much décolletage or, God forbid, a side split and one risks what has now become known in common parlance as “doing a Raquel Welch”, who didn’t so much upstage the bride at her son’s ­wedding as eclipse her completely.And so, paralysed by the uncertainty of it all, the majority of “immediate family” wedding snaps feature the loving couple, a couple of blokes chilling in their usual suits, and two middle-aged women looking deeply uncomfortable in unforgiving taffeta and a hat that resembles an upturned lamp shade.Or, in Sarah Ferguson’s case, a titfer reminiscent of a stewardess for a s Eastern Bloc airline. Then, to keep up appearances for the family photo, Sarah had to hover nervously behind the gimlet-eyed former father-in-law who has ignored her for the past  years.But worst of all, she had to stand by and watch Prince Harry and his glossy new we sweep in and steal bride Eugenie’s thunder with news of their impending baby.A child, I might add, with the added sting of bumping the bride and her sister Beatrice even further down the line of succession.Far from feeling like a “royal wedding”, it bore all the hallmarks of a Hello! or OK!-funded celebrity shindig, or worse, an excerpt from US prime-time soap opera The Royals, starring Elizabeth Hurley.Take the, er, crowds gathered outside Windsor’s St George’s Chapel.“Who are you hoping to catch a glimpse of ” asked a TV reporter.“George Clooney,” came the cheerful reply.Someone  was hoping for David Beckham. They got neither.Both couples claimed other commitments but, given that they all took centre stage at Harry and Meghan’s nuptials and the Beckhams also made the cut for William and Kate’s big day, perhaps they felt this wasn’t A-list enough Instead, we had to make do with, among others, models Naomi Campbell, Cara ­Delevingne and Kate Moss, X Factor judges Robbie Williams and Ayda Field, and actresses Demi Moore and Liv Tyler.Some of whom uploaded gushing videos from the event and Instagram photos of their outfits with hashtag plugs for ­ious clothing brands.At a “royal” wedding  The notoriously traditional Queen Mother must be turning in her grave.There will be the modernisers within the palace walls who regard this as “progress” for a monarchy that, as they see it, must appeal to a younger generationit is to survive.But to my mind, it’s the complete opposite.The pomp, ceremony, tradition, duty and, most importantly, ­mystique of the royals is what sustains them.This wedding — between a “Princess” who performs no royal duties and her Jack of tequila trade — has shone a ­spotlight on the blindingly obvious threat that, once the dutul Queen and Prince Philip are no longer with us, the ­“modern” monarchy will continue to make ever decreasing circles until the taxpayer finally decides, “Hang on — they’re just like us” and the game will be up.With this #royalwedding where even the bride’s mother, left, Instagrammed a designer plug “for my amazing dress” that threat has just come one step closer.RITA ORA is promoting her new album Phoenix. “It’s my first global release of an album.I’m really excited to express my music to the world,” she says.But why the seemingly ­regular need to, er, express her breasts at the same time After all, Ed Sheeran has never posed in just his kecks and he’s sold  squillion records.ANGRY passengers on a flight from London Heathrow to Istanbul intervened to stop Home Office officials from deporting Somalian Yaqub Ahmed.“I know he’s scared,” protested one, before leading a chant of: “Take him off the plane, take him off the plane.”Though probably not as scared as the -year-old girl who was gang-raped in London by Ahmed and two of his equally unsavoury friends – the crime for which he was being deported before these witless do-gooders stepped in.Pitully, the officials capitulated and Ahmed is still in this country awaiting our next move.Meanwhile, as some of the passengers virtue-signalled their liberal credentials by posting footage of the showdown, perhaps they could now be identied and charged with obstructing the course of justice Or, at the very least, be asked to welcome the delightful Mr Ahmed into their own homes until such time as his removal can be rearranged Let’s seetheir liberalism extends to putting their own teenage daughters at risk.PIZZAS and pies must shrink to tackle obesity, claim new official guidelines from Public Health England.Sigh. Amazing, isn’t it, how millions of people manage to stay slim by eating healthily and doing moderate exercise while advocating the same mindset to their children Radical, I know, buta pizza is large, how about sharing it Or perhaps not buying it at all Or is a slice of personal responsibility too hard to swallow CHANNING Tatum and Jessie J are dating.We know this because they’ve been spotted ­laughing together at a mini-golf course.Ah yes, those heady, early months of dating when you’re presenting the best side of yourself and pretending you just love doing kooky stuff like ­hitting a ball into the clown’s mouth or paddling in pointless circles around the local ­boating lake.Then the eager-to-please phase passes and, before you know it, you’re watching ­separate TV shows in dferent parts of the house. And what a blessed relief it is too.QUESTION Time is holding a series of auditions for potential David Dimbleby replacements such as Kirsty Wark, Emily Maitlis, Nick Robinson and Julie Etchingham.They are each chairing a  of politicians and journalists in front of a live audience – the only dference being the programmes won’t be broadcast.Meaning that every last one will be far better than the real thing where, with a few notable exceptions, participants now sanitise their every utterance for fear of being publicly mauled by the kangaroo court of social media.GWYNETH  Paltrow and her new husband Brad Falchuk now refer to them- selves as “The Faltrows”. Let’s just hope that German ice skater Paul Boll doesn’t take a shine to Jane Horrocks.THE SUN has ­partnered with the Movember Foundation to help raise funds and awareness for men’s health issues by ­encouraging people to grow a sponsored ­moustache.Count me in.Post-menopause, this is the look I’m aiming for.AN “invisible” super-yacht has been invented for ­billionaires who value their privacy.Costing £million, it is coated in mirrored glass which, according to the designer, makes it “disappear between water and sea”.Er, doesn’t that mean other vessels will smash into it Still, at least it will sink ­privately. KATE SILVERTON asks her six-year-old daughter each day: “How did you fail today ”The Strictly contestant, who advocates taking kids outside their comfort zone by trying boxing or climbing, adds: “You are not ­trying hard enoughyou haven’t failed.”Perhaps give skying a miss though, eh ANT McPARTLIN and estranged we Lisa ­Armstrong received their decree nisi yesterday.Meaning that in six weeks’ time, the petitioner can apply for the decree absolute as long as everyone is agreed on the ision of cash and assets.In other words – as anyone who’s orced will know – this is when the arguments really begin.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. But Labour need this supposedly impartial Speaker to help stop the ­referendum verdict being enacted and perhaps set up another vote.Bercow, incredibly, wants a NEW bullying inquiry. A People’s Probe, perhaps, aimed at securing a dferent result.Labour’s hypocrisy is off the chart. They can never hold a credible position on bullying or sex harassment again.They even attacked the media for covering the scandal, which was only unearthed at all by the public interest journalism of The Sun and others.For diehard Remainers, Bercow must be shored up at all costs. Sex abuse victims can go to hell and Leave voters too.SURPRISE, surprise. Brussels wants an even more craven surrender from Theresa May tonight. Are they for real We voted to leave. Our MPs voted to quit the Customs Union. Yet the EU seriously insists we must stay in it anyway until it decides otherwise .And, not satisfied with its contempt for our democracy and sovereignty, it aims to destroy the United Kingdom itself by iding Northern Ireland from Britain, which no PM could accept.Brussels seeks to cripple our trading future while demanding Mrs May risks the destruction of her Cabinet, her ­Government, a second referendum or a General Election. But it falls to Britain, they say, to be “constructive”.No Deal looks nailed on from here, doesn’t it  And no wonder.PANIC on the streets of Westminster: Brexit is a stalemate and we’re all doomed.Except, in the real world, pay is rising at . per cent, . above inflation and the fastest in nearly ten years. Unemployment fell to its lowest in  years.Our economy looks far more resilient than the doom-mongers forecast.Yes, No Deal may cause chaos. title: inside snake church kentucky
story: As the deadly strychnine, which can cause muscle spasms, convulsions and asphyxiation, begins to take hold, Pastor Chris Wolford has to sit down on the altar, struggling to breathe and sweating profusely. Chris had mixed a white powder with water to make a clear liquid in the glass jar, before drinking from the supposed poison.But just minutes later the preacher is up on his feet dancing and praising God while swinging the - eerily motionless but still alive - snake through the air. Shockingly Pastor Chris Wolford was just  when he watched his dad haemorrhage to death from a snake bite during a service.His brother also died from the same dangerous practices - but he refuses to lose faith in God and the “Signs” religion. The faith is practised in the Appalachian mountains of Kentucky, Virginia and West Virginia and is based on a literal interpretation of a passage in the bible Mark : which says: “They shall take up serpents andthey drink any deadly thing, it shall not hurt them they shall lay hands on the sick, and they shall recover.”Earlier this year dramatic footage emerged of Pastor Cody Coots, who was almost killed by a rattlesnake during a ritual at another church in Kentucky.Many of the religion’s churches - only a handful of which still remain open - are often closed to outsiders and cameras – particularly as snake handling is illegal in Virginia and Kentucky.But Sun Online was granted exclusive access to one of Chris’s church in Squire, West Virginia - which he says is “open to all”.Before the service, Chris paces up and down, cries and prays as he gets ready to lead his congregation.Music is a huge part of the faith, and as the two guitarists and drummer start playing their mixture of blues and country music, Chris starts to preach.His mother Vicie, , comes to the front and begins spinning round and round, eyes closed as her son praises Jesus.Chris then lights a torch in a glass bottle and Vicie holds it next to her neck, without flinching and leaving no sign of any burn marks.The pastor quickly takes the hissing rattlesnake out of its wooden box and begins swinging it in the air.At some point he throws the snake to the floor and stands on it.The service ends with singing and testimonies from iniduals about how God has saved them, before everyone cheerfully gathers in the basement to share dinner - next to Chris’s snake den.Exhausted Chris sits down and tells me it can take him days to recover but nevertheless he’ll be back the next week to do it all again.Set back off the main road just a few miles from the border of Virginia and West Virginia, the small wooden church looks similar to the dozens of others that dot the rural Bible Belt area.The serpent-handling churches are believed to have originated as early as the s - and are an offshoot of the Pentecostal faith.In the past six years,  there have been three recorded deaths in the US from snake bites during religious services.Chris does not advertise that his church practices serpent handling on the outside – after receiving threats to burn down the building from rival Christian groups who believe the practice is against the word of God.Chris, a recovered drug addict, set up the church after he said: “God saved him” from addictions to crystal meth, cocaine and pain pills - and his congregation has grown from just three to over  in just two years.He decided to open his own church after the death of his brother Randy, who was also a pastor in the faith.Many members of the congregation claim that they have been healed from other addictions such as alcoholism as well as illnesses such as lupus and heart conditions.“I guess people, think that by taking up serpents that were crazy. But the Bible saysI be a fool, I be a fool for Christ,” Chris said.Weve had people healed just in the past few months, even a little baby of about nine months old, who had a fever and couldnt stop vomiting.Ive been healed twice. When I broke my ribs in a car wreck, I remember walking into church in so much pain and I could hardly breathe and somebody put their hands on my ribs and I walked out a dferent person.“When I was on drugs I wasnt even living. All that dope, all that alcohol, all those parties and things that I would go and think ‘boy Im having fun.“It wasnt even until God come into my le that I actually knew what it was like to live.“Out of all the dope Ive ever done I tell people theres no greater feeling than the power of God moving, on you and through you.“When God moves on you to take up those serpents, words can’t describe that feeling. It aint me. Its the power of God.”Services at the House of the Lord Jesus are similar to those practiced by other Pentecostal faiths - except that followers here use snakes, fire and poison in their worship.They are held every Sunday and can last between  minutes to four hours long depending on how many people feel “overcome with the spirit”, want to testy about their experiences or be healed.The snakes are always brought to the service in their wooden boxes but arent always brought out.Chris had explained earlier how he wouldn’t take out the snakes unless he felt the “holy spirit was with him” a sensation he says “is better felt than described”.Throughout it all, the snake never bites anyone around it or attempts to, and almost looks leless, until Chris puts it down on the pulpit and it coils into a ball.During the fascinating spectacle, the frenzied churchgoers clap, dance, scream and shout some even appear to speak in tongues.Afterwards Chris, who suffers from liver problems and is unable to work, is exhausted, sweating and breathless.He tells me afterwards he had to rush to the bathroom to vomit mid-service: “Sometimes the spirit comes on so strong it makes you sick,” he says.Three people come forward to be healed or to ask for prayers for loved ones. The congregations gathers around them and lay their hands on them.“Outside of believing in the five signs of the Gospel I dont think we’re much dferent from any other church.“When God moves in that way we participate in taking up the serpents and whatever  he may ask it to be, fire, poison, pray for the sick, speak in tongues, cast out devils.“We don’t worship the snake, we worship the Lord Jesus Christ, but in the Bible Luke tells us that he gives us power to tread on the scorpions and serpents and nothing shall hurt us by no means.James Bowman, , a mechanic from West Virginia, said he came to the church for the first time two months ago after seeing a video of a service online and believes “finding Jesus” has finally cured him from his lelong alcoholism.“It was the serpents that attracted me here,” he said.“I was a full blown alcoholic but as soon as I saw him lt those snakes that was it for me and I haven’t touched a drop of alcohol since and I don’t plan to. I’ve got my le back.”James now brings his we Crystal, , to the church - along with their three grandchildren, Elaila, , Justin, , and Aubrey, , who sit in the front row mesmerised and unafraid during the snake-handling service.Pastor Chris was just  years old when he saw his dad receive a fatal bite from a rattlesnake as he was preaching.Mack Ray Wolford died a slow and painful death as the snake’s poison coursed round his body stopping his blood from clotting, causing him to haemorrhage to death - taking his last breathe around nine hours later.Almost  years later, Chris watched as his beloved brother Mack “Randy” Wolford die in the same way – bitten by a deadly rattlesnake while he was preaching during an outdoor service.Chris tearfully recalls trying to give his brother - who he described as his “best friend” - CPR and how blood gushed out of his lungs with every compression.“I hated to lose my dad. I loved my dad. And I loved my brother more than anything. He was my pastor, my brother, my best friend. “I mean there wasnt a day that went by that I didnt call him or he didnt call me - we were very, very close. Not a day goes by I don’t think about him but he found something that was worth dying for, something that he loved more than he loved his self. “The day he got bit - and it was the same with my father - when we asked ‘do you want to go to the hospital ’ They could - we dont force nobody not to go. But they chose not to go. They were willing to give their lives for what they believe. “I tell people this,it aint worth dying for, it aint worth having and it aint worth believing in.“With my father and my brother, they kept the faith. They fought a good fight, they kept the faith, they finished the race, the course and theyre at peace or with the Lord now.“And I dont even thinkthey could come back, theyd want to come back. I believe that they’re just happy where they are.“The night he died - my brother - I remember sitting at his feet and I told him, I promised, that wed see each other again, that its not going to be the last time we saw each other and Im going to do my best to keep that promise. So one day we can meet on the other side.”And Chris, who has been bitten several times, the last time just two months ago, says that while he doesn’t want to die from a serpent bite, he would be willing to die for his beliefshe had to.“Its not for us to question why these things happen - it’s to believe,” he said.“I watched my father die that way, I watched my brother die that way and its a hard way to die, but I hopeits ever asked from me from the Lord, Im willing to do it.“I’d rather go that way than with a needle in my arm.” Chris’s we Judy comes in part-way through the service and stands at the back.She also lost a family member - her brother - who got bitten while serpent handling and she is terried of losing her husband the same way.“Of course every Sunday I worry it might be the last time I see him. I worry about him getting bit.“I’d rather he could worship God another way - without drinking that poison or holding those snakes. “But it’s his choice and there ain’t nothing I can do to change that.”Chris keeps around half a dozen fully grown snakes in the basement underneath his church - including venomous timber rattlesnakes and copperhead snakes.He also has around four babies after he was given a pregnant snake. Usually the snakes are caught from the surrounding countryside, and kept with heat lamps in glass cages and fed mice.A picture of Jesus watches over the snake den. Chris rejects any claims he mistreats the snakes - and has past inspections from local authorities.“We take good care of these snakes. Some of them I reared since they were babies.“If any of them refuse to eat we put them back out in the wild - some of them just won’t eat in captivity and we don’t want them to die so we turn them back out.”Bizarrely Chris seems terried of the snakes when he uses his snake hook to display them for the camera.The jittery snakes rattle and hiss at every opportunity - the very opposite of how the rattlesnake in the service limply allowed itself to be swing around. “You can see how scared I am of them when God is not with me,” he says.“But when the Spirit is with you all fear just goes.“Anything is possible with the Lord.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 180000 brits are owed 5000 each after having their benefits underpaid by bungling officials
story: The Government will pay an average of £, to , disabled or ill claimants who were short-changed for years.The Department for Work and Pensions announced it faces a bill of nearly £billion for the blunder - three times as much as previously thought.It is the latest embarrassment for the department which is already under fire over the rollout of Universal Credit.Earlier this year, the DWP admitted it had underpaid thousands of claimants of Employment Support Allowance, which is intended for those too ill to work.Officials claimed , people were affected, with a total estimated cost of £million.But today they published an update which shows the numbers involved are much higher than previously thought.A total of , claimants are owed an average of £, each, with some due to be paid as much as £,.The overall bill to the taxpayer will be £million, most of which will be paid out over the next two years.Just  per cent of those affected have been paid the benefits they are owed.Civil servants are in the process of contacting the other , claimants and hope to be finished by next April.They are prioritising the most serious cases including those of people who are now terminally ill.Labour MP Neil Coyle blasted: Another criminal let-down of thousands of disabled people by a callous Government and a chaotic DWP.A spokesman for the DWP said: “Anyone affected by this historic error will receive all of the money they are entitled to.That is why we have created a dedicated team of over  staff to examine cases, and have paid back around £million so far.“We have worked with charities and other disability organisations to make sure that we are providing the right support to all affected claimants and are hiring and allocating more staff to do that.”

title: theresa may needs to say no
story: The proposal to keep us shackled to the EU for another year beyond the transition period is an outrageous non-starter.We have compromised far too much. Mrs May cannot go further than her over-generous Chequers offer. This latest ruse is an insult she must repel.We would be in the farcical position of voting to Leave in June , yet still bound by Brussels rules until December  at the earliest. Which means continuing free movement, another £billion of public money tipped into EU coffers and no say over any of it.The Irish border problem is an overhyped stunt. The EU admits it would never build one even in a No Deal. Nor would we. Yet we are told we must buckle to their every whim to “avoid” such a border. Who would build it Mrs May is playing with fire even ­considering this new surrender.Unless she can give a date when we will leave the EU and ALL its major institutions she cannot claim to have fulfilled the referendum vote.When, PM, will we take back control FOR two years Leavers have had to suffer political has-beens being given s to bellyache about Brexit.Tony Blair, Nick Clegg and Michael Heseltine yesterday crossed the line into outright treachery.How  to describe their sickening appeal to the EU to frustrate exit negotiations long enough to buy Remainers time for a second referendum   A plea orchestrated to coincide with Mrs May’s crucial Brussels summit.Instead of backing Britain, and our historic decision, these meddling losers conspire with the EU to undermine our interests. The hypocrisy, arrogance and blinkered ­stupidity are jaw-dropping.Blair’s cabal claim to be motivated by “our support for democracy”.  It is a lie.A second referendum does not serve democracy. How could it  It is a naked attempt to reverse the biggest mandate in our history before it is enacted. It is the surest way to destroy trust in our ancient system and unleash chaos.John Major never consulted the public before signing away our rights to the new EU in . Nor did Blair when he threw open our borders.It was THEIR contempt for voters that built the resentment which led to Brexit.Now they are pouring petrol on the fire.YOU may not have heard of Noor Khan.She won a George Cross for bravery helping the resistance in occupied France during World War Two. She was tortured by the Gestapo but never cracked. The Nazis executed her in .Noor was just . A proper heroine.And a British Muslim.Many candidates’ pictures could grace the new £ note. title: emmanuel macron angela merkel brexit summit theresa may
story: The French and German leaders were spotted enjoying a pint in the centre of Brussels after dinner with other EU bosses.The pair were joined by Belgian PM Charles Michel and Luxembourgs Xavier Bettel for drinks in the citys main square.It came after all EU leaders enjoyed a dinner of mushrooms and turbot at the European Council summit.Before the meal, Mrs May gave a -minute speech setting out her proposals for a Brexit deal - then left to dine alone.She was hoping to secure agreement for a special Brexit summit to take place next month where a deal could finally be signed off.But Eurocrats told her there are no plans for such a meeting because the two sides havent made enough progress in ongoing talks.A spokesman said: “The EU leaders stand ready to convene a European Council,and when reports that decisive progress has been made.“For now, EU is not planning to organize an extraordinary summit on Brexit in November.”The news could push the deal back to December - setting up a crunch Commons vote just days before Christmas.The EU leaders refused to discuss Brexit as they drank in Brussels last night.Asked about the issue, Mrs Merkel quipped: Please, it’s a wonderful evening... let’s not spoil it.And quizzed about the encounter this morning, Mr Bettel said: It was very good. We had french fries and a beer, we are in Brussels so it was very nice.Mr Macron added: I’m always happy and open to share a drink with dferent leaders - and Theresa May will be very much welcome.The PM today risked fury from her own MPs by confirming she is considering a new plan to extend the post-Brexit transition period.EU leaders have proposed a longer transition, leaving Britain tied to the bloc until the end of , as a way of solving the Irish border issue.Mrs May said this morning: A further idea that has emerged, and it is an idea at this stage, is to create an option to extend the implementation period for a matter of months.

title: theresa may britain freedom eu
story: Not just the Brexiters. Her vital Scottish MPs. The moderates. The Remainers. Also the DUP on whom she relies.Barely enough people back her ­Chequers offer to hold their Christmas do in a Downing Street cupboard.And The Sun shares all their gloom.Mrs May admits we could extend the transition till . That the Irish backstop cannot be finite, so unless we have a watertight exit clause Brussels could lock us in its Customs Union for good.She must NEVER allow that.Yesterday the German chief economist of Deutsche Bank insisted thatwe can do deals with the US, Japan, Canada and the Commonwealth, Britain WILL thrive after Brexit and outstrip the EU.Exactly what Brussels fears.If the PM cannot secure our freedom to do all that, the game is up.NOT long ago crime was falling relentlessly.That’s all in the past. There has been an explosion of murders, rapes, robberies, knings, thefts and burglaries.Drug gangs rule our streets.Cuts have gone too far. We need more cops and ato Stop and Search.The upcoming Budget must free up more money to maintain law and order.But chief constables need to get a grip.Sergeant Richard Cooke, head of the West Midlands Police Federation, talks sense when he says officers waste time probing non-criminal “hate speech” and appeasing the “court of Twitter”.Our police chiefs need to get off their smartphones, ignore the “social justice” mob and refocus on keeping citizens safe.MUCH of the world is looking on aghast as Britain persecutes its own soldiers.Our No ally certainly is. Ex-Nato Commander General David Petraeus says the witch-hunt into veterans of the Troubles is wrecking our reputation as a reliable military partner. It may lead to “risk aversion” among current troops and “potentially limit their use of force”.So these probes have disastrous military implications as well as being an indefensible way to treat our forces.The Government must end them now. If legal challenges spring up, fight them.Grow a spine. Do the right thing.LABOUR considers the well-off a grasping elite whose cash must be given to the poor.They never consider how to grow an economy and create more wealth for all.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit deal theresa may brussels summit
story: Brexiteers called on the PM to get some steel - and warned they will block any attempt to pay in more to the EUs budget.But Mrs Mays ally Jeremy Hunt stood up for her - claiming the only reason Brexit talks are in trouble is because of her firm negotiating strategy.The PM said yesterday that she would consider keeping Britain tied to the EU for an extra year in order to reach a Brexit deal.But Brexit backers in her own party have responded with anger to the plans for extending the transition period until the end of .Iain Duncan Smith told the BBC: I couldnt understand why we would offer to extend the transition period when we still havent got anything back in .By extending the backstop we are likely to fall straight into the next budget of the EU which will mean tens of billions of pounds extra to be paid across to the EU.We are in a negotiation but at the moment it begins to look more like a capitulation than a negotiation.We have got to get some steel in our backbone.Brexiteers are threatening to use a Commons vote to block any extra money going to the EU beyond the £billion already promised.They want to amend the Finance Bill to ban ministers from handing additional cash to Brussels without the permission of Parliament.Andrea Jenkyns told the : Its absurd that there is to be a Budget before the final Brexit deal.That is effectively writing a blank cheque to the EU and that leaves the danger that Article  may be extended with full funding.And Priti Patel urged Mrs May to channel the spirit of Margaret Thatcher by refusing to fork over any money to the EU budgetEurocrats continue to stonewall.Mr Hunt insisted the PMs tough stance is working - because she has refused to fold to the EUs demands.He told the BBC today: The reason why this week has been dficult is because Theresa May has not buckled. She has held firm. She has stuck to her principles.It is precisely because she has not capitulated that we have not concluded this agreement.The one thing I would say to my colleagues is that the great strength of the EU in these negotiations is that the  EU nations have remained united.We now need to do the same behind Theresa May to maximise her negotiating leverage in Brussels and make sure she does come back with that deal that honours the letter and spirit of the referendum decision.But Mrs May faces opposition from within her own Cabinet - Scotland Secretary David Mundell told No yesterday he wont accept a longer transition period.Scottish Tories are angry at the prospect of Britain signing up to the Common Fisheries Policy for another year.The EUs Brexit envoy Michel Barnier today said a deal is  per cent done.But he added: I’m convinced a deal is necessary, I’m still not sure we’ll get one.

title: driver forces couple dumping baby clothes pickup rubbish
story: The Good Samaritan blasted the pair after spotting them leave two full bags of rubbish at the corner of Dyson Road in Halax, West Yorkshire, at around pm on Monday.The shameless man and woman even claimed they were dumping the bags for charity when the driver intervened and demanded they stop littering near his home.When challenged, the woman said she was entitled to leave it in the street because she was giving the items to people who needed them.But the couples excuses cut no ice with their accusers and they were forced to pick up their bags and haul them away.The local council is now investigating the incident and has said authorities will not hesitate to prosecute those responsible for fly tipping.Video footage of the confrontation - filmed by a car passenger - shows him wind down his window and order the couple to go back and pick them bags up”.A blonde woman approaches the car and says: Its a bag full of clothes, for babies.When the man tells her the roadside is not a clothes bank, she replies: Well, it used to be there.He blasts: Go back and pick them up. F****** dump rubbish here, we live here.The car follows the pair down the street to the spot where the bags were dumped, as the woman protests: I was giving it to the people who needed the baby clothes.Unmoved by her story, the man replies: Theres no people on that corner who need it, so pick them up.He then spots a large object protruding from one of the open bags and asks: Does that look like baby clothes to you ”To which she responds: There are toys as well.The couple then pick up their bags and slope off, as the passenger brands them disgusting.The woman - who still apparently feels she has done nothing wrong - turns and asks: What, for helping people out Infuriated by her lack of remorse, the man shouts back: Dumping stuff on the floor. Who you helping  Yourself The hero who filmed the incident did not wish to be identied but viewers who saw the footage on social media were full of praise for his efforts.Tayyab Zahoor said: “That’s disgusting. Good job making them clean it.”Elaine White wrote: Well done to the lads that stopped and said something. Your community should be proud of you.Dilshad Hussain added: Make them clean the whole street next time.Calderdale Council told The Sun Online: “The Council does all it can to stop fly-tipping and will not hesitate to prosecute those responsible.Although this instance has not been previously reported to us, we will now investigate, as we do with all reports.“In all cases, having as much information as possible helps to bring successful prosecutions, so the Council is urging people to come forwardthey witness any fly-tipping.West Yorkshire Police said the incident has not been reported to officers.

title: doctors remove eleven live worms baby eye
story: The five-month-old caught a horric roundworm infection from the neighbours pet.The child, known as Dong Dong, was taken to was taken to the Xi’an No.  Hospital in north-west China after mum noticed irritation in the tot’s eye.Medics examined Dong Dong and found several wriggling worms on the surface of the eyeball.Using special tweezers doctors were able to remove the grim creatures, which are believed to be Thelazia callipaeda – a parasitic roundworm.It took  minutes for doctors to remove the worms, plucking them out one at a time using tweezers.The worms most often affect cats, dogs and other animals, but can be passed on to humans.Termed ‘oriental eye worm’, the majority of cases occur in Asia, where it occurs predominantly in rural communities with poor living and socioeconomic standards, according to the UK Department ofor Environment, Food and Rural Affairs.A small number of human cases have been reported in Europe in areas where the infection is well established in domestic animals, like dogs and cats.Usually cases in humans cause clinical signs of exudative conjunctivitis, watery eyes and pain, but asymptomatic infection is recorded.If youre concerned you may have a roundworm infection you should see a doctor.Dong Dong is continuing to receive treatment but is expected to make a full recovery.

title: michel barnier brexit nostalgic
story: Brussels’ chief negotiator said people were “not told all the consequences” before choosing to quit the bloc in June .Speaking on French radio, he said: I wouldnt confuse belief in the free market with nostalgia.Mr Barnier added: Brexit cant be soft. It has innumerable consequences. It was chosen by the British.Were they well informed at the time they voted  They were not told all the consequences.And he warned the talks could still collapse over the thorny Irish border issue after this week’s EU summit ended in stalemate.The Frenchman told Theresa May that whatever happens the split from Brussels will be “much more grave for Britain” than the rest of Europe.He said EU capitals were preparing emergency solutions to cope with a no deal Brexit but that a crash out would still be extremely serious.Mr Barnier said: I dont want to impose a hard Brexit. A hard Brexit is the absence of a deal and I am working for a deal.The Frenchman also blasted Eurosceptics saying that they had not been able to prove there will be any added value in Brexit.His remarks came as Tottenham Hotspur boss Mauricio Pochettino described the decision to leave as a car crash and urged Mrs May to put the brakes on.The Argentinian said he feels sorry for the British public who still don’t know the consequences of Brexit.He said: I feel so sorry because it’s a situation that should be dealt with by people who have all the information, who know the reality.“It’s so unfair to put the responsibility on the people because there are consequences.We said Brexit, we bought into an idea. But afterwards, who suffers  We don’t know.

title: woman breeds zonkey only uk zebra donkey pet
story: Kristine Turner, , cant rein in her excitement over the adorable foal, named Zippy, after it was born at her farm in Somerset.The pet-mad mum-of-two had been champing at the bit for her pet zebra Ziggy and donley Rag to mate.Id wonder every yearshe was pregnant or just a bit fat, Kristine told The Sun Online.You could put the randiest of animals out there - which I have done in the past - and nothing!”Just putting the two together isn’t enough to guarantee that they will mate, which is very dficult to do because of the black and white dferences between the species.But finally after donkeys years of waiting the amazing zonkey was born.Kristine added: “It feels amazing to be honest, I couldn’t believe it. When I looked out the window I was just going ‘Oh my god, oh my god!’”She says that she didnt even have a vet confirm that the zebra was pregnant because she didnt want to cause the animal any distress.Although Zippy is one of the first zonkies to be born in Britain, others have been brought over from abroad to live here.Three zonkies were born in Colchester Zoo in the s following the accidental mating of a zebra and an ass, and more recently several zebra hybrids from America were rescued by a UK donkey sanctuary.A zonkey belongs to a group of hybrids called ‘zebroids’, in which a zebra mates with a dferent kind of equine animal.Other zebroids include zorses , and zebmules .Kristine’s dad Bill Turner, , is a race horse trainer who made headlines when he “broke in” a zebra of his own back in  so that he could successfully ride it like a horse, despite zebras being notoriously panicky and near-impossible to domesticate.It was after seeing her father’s remarkable feat that she had a zebra of her own brought over from Germany.

title: pro eu activists set to march through london calling for second brexit referendum as pressure mounts on theresa may
story: Up to , Remainers will attempt to put pressure on Theresa May to call a so-called peoples vote.It comes as the PM is being squeezed by her own MPs who are furious Britain could remain tied to the EU for an extra year.Tomorrows march, which will go from Park Lane to Westminster, is set to be the biggest second referendum protest yet.Speakers will include Sadiq Khan, Delia Smith and Vince Cable.Its also being supported by celebs including actor Brian Cox and ex-footballer Gary Lineker.Donors have paid for members of the public to be bussed in from all around the country.And MPs from all parties are backing the demo.During the event, Lib Dem activists are set to hand out Brexit fudge to mock Labours confused position on the EU.MP Tom Brake said: “Jeremy Corbyn and the Labour leadership have defied us all with their ‘Brexit fudge’.Inspired by Willy Wonka himself, the Labour’s opposition to Brexit is just ‘pure imagination’.

title: uk weather forecast weekend freezing latest
story: Below freezing temperatures in the small hours of Monday will see widespread frost across much of the country in a chilly start to the week.Saturday will see sunshine for many as southerly winds and clear skies help the thermometers reach as high as C in some areas.The warm weather will centre mainly around southern parts of England and Wales.Stronger winds, thick cloud and the odd patch of rain in Scotland and Northern Ireland will see temperatures here hover around the mid-teens.But it will still be unseasonably warm as the average UK temperature for this time of year is a much chillier C.A Met Office forecaster told The Sun Online: “It’ll be cloudy overnight with a few frost hollows dropping below freezing.“A cold front will sweep across the country from the northwest reaching the southeast by Sunday night.“That front will leave some colder air behind it meaning that across a wide area of the country we will get frozen temperatures and a frost on Monday morning.“The rest of the day will be a lovely fresh day with temperatures  or  degrees lower than this weekend.“Tuesday also looks like it will be dry with some frost in the morning in the central areas of the UK with similar temperatures to Monday.”Daytime temperatures could hit as low as C on Monday and snow is expected on the Scottish Highlands.And a chilling Halloween is on the cards as snow is expected to hit parts early as next Friday.But Brits in the Midlands and the South dont need to worry about being snowed in just yet.A Met Office spokesperson told The Sun Online: There is quite a reasonable possibility of some snow for the high ground in the North.Theres always a chance up in the hills of Scotland, the further north you go the more likely you are to get snow this time of year.Next week, its getting colder especially towards the end of the week.And another freezing evening is predicted for tonight.It will be particularly cold in the South East where fog is also likely to set in.

title: nick clegg hypocrisy facebook

title: eggheads cj de mooi bankrupt
story: The former BBC quiz master filed his bankruptcy paperwork with Reading Insolvency Service on September .It’s believed he racked up a fortune in legal bills fighting extradition to the Netherlands where police wanted to question him about a confession in his  autobiography that he may have killed a mugger  years ago.The star’s book My Journey From the Streets to the Screen said of the incident in Amsterdam: “I was in a phone box and this old guy, obviously a massive drug user, came up behind me with a kne in his hand.He told me to turn around, open my bag and give him whatever was inside.I punched him so hard in the face, knocked the kne out of his hand and threw him in the canal. I fully suspect I killed him. Ive no idea what happened to him.Cold case cops in Holland had De Mooi - real name Joseph Connagh - nicked at Heathrow Airport in September  after filming in South Africa.Later The Sun revealed how -year-old German drter Norbert Dichtl – among  bodies hauled from the canals in  -was found to have died in an almost identical way to that described by de Mooi.But a court later ruled prosecutors bungled the extradition paperwork - and a European warrant should not have been issued without a domestic one.The Insolvency Service will now look at liquidating the star’s assets to pay off any creditors, though their identities are not disclosed in documents.In July de Mooi, of Caldicot, Monmouthshire, set up a Just Giving page to raise £, toward his legal costs while denying he wrote the incriminating passages in his book.“The last two and a half years have been hell for me.I was accused of a horric crime which I can prove I absolutely did not commit.”Yesterday he refused to comment.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: daniel hannan boycott referendum
story: Hundreds of thousands of protesters are expected to take to central London’s streets today for the biggest march yet for a People’s Vote to overturn ’s result.Speaking ahead of it, Tory MEP Daniel Hannan called on the .million who voted out to stay away from any second pollMPs succeed in enforcing one.Mr Hannan told Al Jazeera show UpFront: “A second referendum would be utterly illegitimate. I would not vote in it, because we’ve just had a referendum.“When the British people have given a very clear mandate, and the unelected peers and the elites then turnaround and undo it, we should not play that game.”But a former MI chief yesterday gave his backing to a second vote as the only way to reunite the nation.Sir John Sawers, who was in charge of the Secret Intelligence Service from -, said: “I believe that all of us, the advocates of Britain leaving the EU as well as those arguing we should still remain a member, should support a second referendum.“A national decision by referendum would at least be final and would allow us to start healing the isions that have opened up over the Brexit question.Sir John also claimed that Brexit will make the UK more vulnerable to attacks like the Russian novichok poisoning in Salisbury.The Kremlin thought it could “pick on Britain and bully us because we were looking weak”, he argued.Sir John added: “The Americans to some extent are walking away from their relationship with Europe, and we are walking away from the relationship with the European Union. title: the top nagging questions that drive brits made revealed
story: A poll of  adults found almost nine in  have spent their days wonderingthey turned things off, picked up important items and locked up when they left the house that morning.Other common niggling questions include did I pick my keys up, did I turn off the light and did I turn off my hair straighteners.But once a worry sets in, it can be hard to shake it off with  per cent admitting that a nagging thought is often all they can think about until they can make sure it’s OK.Eight in ten adults, polled by home improvement window specialists Independent Network, have even turned back or ed home to put their mind at ease, despite the time and money it adds to their journey.A spokesman for Independent Network, a membership of trusted local window  door installers powered by VEKA, said: “From wonderingwe’ve left a window open to questioningthe lights are still on, there are many niggling questions we ask ourselves each day.“And once you have that thought, evenyou are certain you did it, it can be hard to forget about it completely until you can go and check.“For some, it gets so bad, they have to drive back home to make sure their door is locked or the window is closed so they can concentrate on the rest of their day.“But many of these little niggles could cause troublewe did in fact forget to do them, so it’s easy to see why they can play on your mind and lead to a worrying day.“Leaving your door or window open could leave your home at risk, especially when you are at work all day.”The study found did I lock the front door is the most common question Brits ask themselves followed by have I got my phone and do I have my keys.Worrying about what to have for dinner and whether you’ve got everything you need is also at the forefront of the nation’s minds along with concerns that a window has been left open at home.Did I turn off the light, have I locked the car and even did I leave the front door open also appear in the list.Four in  have been so worried they have left something open or unlocked, or turned on, they have called a friend or neighbour to pop back home and double check.And almost one in four have left a spare key with someone so they can get in to their home to make sure things are shut and turned off when they are too far away to check themselves.A third have even left work in the middle of the day, or used their lunch break to go back home to put their mind at rest. Are these niggling doubts our subconscious trying to tell us something One respondent even went back home to check they had turned the hob off to find a fire engine outside and a house full of smoke confirming that they had left it on.A quarter of those polled, via OnePoll, have ed home from work to find they have left a window open while almost one in five have gone back to their car only to find they had left it unlocked.More than one in twenty have also opened their front door to find the iron or their hair straighteners still switched on.But while most niggling worries have usually proved to be unfounded,  per cent are glad to have gone back to check their home.Four in  even went as far as to say they would feel anxious all daythey weren’t able to go back and check something while another  per cent would feel on edge.A spokesman for Independent Network, added: “As a company we are very tuned into how homeowners live their home lives and how busy they are, but even we were surprised by some of the results! It just goes to show that we are all under the same pressures and juggling a million things each day.”

title: samantha markle panto step sister
story: This horrid woman has done nothing but carp at and criticise her half-sister Meghan.It began almost straight after Meghan’s engagement to Prince Harry was announced and carried on through the lead-up to the Royal Wedding and beyond.Only in the past week has Samantha realised that being vile and vindictive has achieved nothing other than making her look like a green-eyed witch .Among her most hurtful outbursts were that Meghan was cold and inhumane and that the marriage was doomed to failure.She was also apparently behind those stupid staged paparazzi shots of Meghan’s dad Thomas trying on suits before the wedding. It was those paid-for photos that led to him having “health problems” and failing to walk his daughter down the aisle.After appearing on every TV and radio outlet that would pay for her bile-fuelled rants, Samantha recently tried to gain entrance to Buckingham Palace to meet Meghan.She was, quite rightly, told by grim-faced security staff to bog off.None of Samantha’s vitriol has stuck and most of the world has fallen almost as head-over-heels in love with Meghan as her besotted husband — especially since the news broke that they are expecting.Given that no one is interested in Samantha’s hysterical attacks on her sister, she wants to bury the hatchet.She has apologised for any past tensions and exclaimed that she’s jumping with joy at the baby news.It’s too little too late, and I’m sure Meghan would agree.Samantha has crossed the line too many times to be forgiven now.If she had shown any loyalty she might have been invited to the ­wedding and welcomed into the royal fold. But instead of acting as a peace-maker, Samantha stirred bad feeling between Meghan and her estranged father.A loving sister would have tried to build bridges, unite family ­factions and show solidarity with Meghan.I’m sure the new Duchess of Sussex would have ­welcomed having family members around her as she adjusted to le in the royal goldfish bowl.In the end, Meghan had only ONE close relative at her wedding, her mum Doria.Along with the absence of the late Princess Diana, it was the day’s only sad note.Samantha could have had a starring role as a loyal sister helping Meghan adjust from successful actress to worldwide megastar.The media would have fallen over themselves to talk to her for insights into her famous sister, but not any more. We are all very tired of Samantha’s negativity and venom.No one has any time for her any more, and for such an attention-seeker that has got to hurt.If she had been kind to Meghan, Samantha would still be relevant. TV stations, magazines and newspapers would be asking her about the mum-to-be and she would be at the heart of all the pregnancy coverage.Instead of being a loyal, loving and supportive source of information about Meghan, Samantha is now ­dismissed as jealous, irrelevant and malicious. No one cares about her opinion any more.Meanwhile, Meghan has won over Australia with a charm offensive that shows no sign of flagging. She and Harry are a true partnership.Unlike the tension between his parents Princess Diana and Prince Charles, Harry is genuinely delighted to see the enthusiasm and love for his we during this tour.Charles would famously get the hump because everyone wanted to meet Diana on royal walkabouts.In contrast, Harry and Meghan are relaxed, spontaneous and genuinely adore each other. It has been good to see them having fun and giving hugs and smiles to the crowds.While Meghan grows in confidence and the public’s affection, Samantha is now an irrelevance.It’s her own fault and she has to live with it. She will always have her nose pressed against the window pane of whatever palace her little sister is in at the time.Still, Sam, there’s always panto, eh ONE of the great joys of my le was watching Disney movies with my daughter when she was growing up.We watched my childhood favourites Dumbo, Bambi and Snow White, then I sat through Beauty And The Beast and The Little Mermaid about two thousand and ten times.So I was bemused to hear that Keira Knightley has banned her three-year-old daughter from ­watching some Disney movies such as Cinderella because the characters are “rescued” by men.This is rather joyless.Cinders might have been wooed by a man dumb enough not to recognise the love of his le until her foot fitted inside a glass slipper, but Belle from Beauty And The Beast is a book-loving, independent girl who tells the handsome but horrible Gaston to sling his hook and falls for the Beast because of the man he is inside. Pocahontas, Tiana, Merida, Rapunzel and especially Mulan are all kick-ass, feisty females.Disney remade Cinderella in  and she was a very dferent character.Keira doesn’t have to let her daughter watch Cinderella when there are so many alternatives available, but she also doesn’t need to be so blinking sanctimonious about it.So Joanna in The Cry is actually in court accused of murdering her sleazebag of a husband after they faked the kidnapping of their dead baby.It’s the last episode tomorrow, when we will find out what the heck has been going on.ButJoanna, played by Jenna Coleman, left, really did kill husband Alistair, I reckon it’s justiable homicide.The ghastly toad sat with his eyemask on and earplugs in, leaving her to deal with a screeching baby all through that epic flight to Australia.Surely on those grounds alone no court would convict her.I ADORED Freddie Mercury and would have gladly given a year of my le to be a fly on the wall at one of his notoriously extravagant and outrageous parties.He was a complete one-off, so I was always rather sceptical and a bit concerned about any film that would try to depict his extraordinary le and capture his sheer showmanship.Thankfully, the makers of new film Bohemian Rhapsody found the ridiculously talented American actor Rami Malek.He doesn’t so much play the part of Freddie but rather inhabits his body and brings him back to le.It’s an Oscar-worthy performance that is both funny and deeply moving and Rami is backed up by the perfectly cast three other members of Queen.Gwilym Lee as Brian May is so uncannily like the ace guitarist that his we Anita Dobson thought she had actually gone back in time, as he’s the spitting image of Brian when the two of them met.The Live Aid sequence, recreating the moment when Freddie and the band blew everyone away with their barnstorming performance, gave me goosebumps.I blubbed a lot during this movie, as well as laughing out loud.It also had me rushing to download all the original Queen albums and rediscovering tracks like Keep Yourself Alive and Doing All Right, as well as the classics such as Killer Queen and We Are The Champions.It’s a cracking film and a love letter to one of the greatest entertainers and most charismatic rock stars of all time. WELL, what a shock and surprise that Girls Aloud’s Nadine Coyle and Cheryl were never best pals. . . said no one ever.It was clear that these two, below in , never really hit it off right from the start when the girls won TV talent show Popstars: The Rivals in  against boyband One True Voice.Back then Nadine was very much the star and lead vocalist, which led to tensions in the group.The girls split into two factions – Nadine and Sarah Harding on one side and Cheryl, Nicola Roberts and ­Kimberley Walsh on the other.Tellingly, Nadine said the girls have never had a big fall-out because they were never really friends in the first place.This is what tends to happen when boy and girl bands are thrown together in a reality show and don’t have a shared history. Cracks appear and there are resentments over who is ­perceived as being ­centre stage.A notable exception are the hugely ­likeable Little Mix, who put all their energies into their music and also to ensuring they give out positive messages about self-esteem and body confidence to their legions of fans.These girls have become genuinely good friends who have each other’s backs and who know that they are stronger together than they would bethey had to stand alone.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm needs to get eu accept clause
story: She needs to persuade the European Union to replace the Northern Ireland backstop with a UK-wide one and to accept an escape clause to show that the UK won’t be trapped in a customs union with the EU ­forever.Influential Cabinet ministers expect the Government to decide on the escape clause it will propose to Brussels in the coming days.The Brexit negotiations will then resume with the EU in the second half of next week.Key Cabinet ministers have one test for the escape clause: Is it legally meaningful. In other words, will it give the UK a genuine opportunity to leave.Just putting the word temporary in front of the phrase ­”customs union” — a solution favoured by some at the heart of Government — won’t be enough for these Secretaries of State.One tells me that it has “got to be legally binding and enforceable. Something that is vague and not enforceable won’t get through Parliament”. All of this makes the newest face at the Cabinet table, the Attorney General Geoffrey Cox, absolutely crucial.Cox is a Brexiteer and one of the finest dozen legal brains in the country. Ministers will defer to him on whether this escape clause is worth the paper it’s written on.As one of those helping to ­coordinate the Brexiteers in government tells me, Cox values his reputation too much to try to spin ministers a line. They are confident he will give them an honest assessment of the escape clause’s worth.“Anything will have to go through the AG,” I’m told by one Government source.Cox’s influence will run throughout this process. I understand that the bulk of the Pizza Club of Cabinet ministers who met on Monday night have agreed not to back the final Brexit deal until they have seen the legal advice.I am told that Michael Gove made clear at Cabinet this week that he couldn’t back any Northern Irish backstop until he had been shown “clear, ­written legal advice” on it.This insistence on seeing the legal advice is meant to prevent a repeat of what happened last December when No gave Brexiteer Cabinet ­ministers assurances about what the backstop meant which were not borne out by events.So, the question becomes: Will the EU be prepared to engage with the UK or will Michel Barnier simply say “non, non” Well, there is a cautious ­optimism in No that the political will to do a deal is beginning to be there on the European side. There is a realisation thatthe EU rejects everything May proposes, there will be no agreement reached — and that will mean a hard border in Ireland, which is what everyone is trying to avoid.Interestingly, there is also a sense thatagreement can be reached on the backstop, then the deal has a better chance of passing through Parliament thanOne of those who has read the draft political declaration tells me that the UK EU future relationship is more to the taste of Tory Brexiteers than expected.May must find a way to get the EU to accept an escape clause, for without that she’ll lose more Cabinet Ministers and her position will be even more vulnerable.GAVIN BARWELL, the Prime Minister’s chief of staff, had the Government’s junior ministers in on Tuesday. He wanted to talk them through Theresa May’s domestic agenda as outlined in her conference speech.He wanted to emphasise that the Government would prioritise its domestic agenda as soon as the meaningful vote on Brexit was through the Commons.Barwell’s comments fit with an expectation in Cabinet that Mrs May will attempt to relaunch her premiership with a domestic focus as soon as the Commons has voted on her Brexit deal.The aim is to create a rationale for keeping May on as Prime Minister after Brexit day. Influential Cabinet ministers are also expecting Mrs May to reshuffle her Cabinet at that point.The thinking is that a freshened-up Cabinet would give the Government a new, post-Brexit feel without a need to replace the Prime Minister. But the chances of Mrs May staying on long after Brexit day in March  have lowered signicantly in the past few days.Before this week, some Tory MPs argued that Mrs May should stay until the Brexit transition was done in December . They said this would mean that a new leader would be able to come in as a fresh face after Brexit and in time for the next General Election.However, the news that the transition could be extended cuts against that argument, as the transition could take you to months away from the next election.Privately, Tories from the Cabinet down acknowledge thatthe transition can be extended, then the case for keeping Mrs May until the end of it is weaker.Rather, it would be better to get a new leader soon after March  to give them a chance to make an impact on both Brexit and domestic policy before the  General Election.THE European Union likes to say that an Irish backstop is needed to protect the Good Friday agreement.But what that ignores is that by changing the nature of Northern Ireland’s relationship with the rest of the UK without consent, the backstop risks being in breach of that agreement.THERESA MAY’S declaration in her party conference speech that austerity is over has raised expectations of big pay rises across the public sector.At Cabinet this week, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, Liz Truss, was keen to hose down this idea. She emphasised that public sector pay deals should be based on retention – eg. how many staff were leaving because the pay isn’t good enough, geographic factors and helping the lowest paid most.I’m told that Mrs Truss told the Cabinet that: “Some pay review bodies have ignored affordability requirements.”I understand Mrs May agreed the Government should get away from the idea of a single figure for public sector pay. Meanwhile, preparations for the Budget continue.This is meant to be a small Budget yet one ­Government source warns it is going to be “bloody contentious”.  Why  Because it will set the baseline for departmental spending ahead of next year’s spending review.THE biggest risk of a leadership challenge to Theresa May comes from cock-up, not conspiracy.The danger for her is not that Brexit ultras organise  letters and send them in simultaneously, forcing a confidence vote in her, but that enough despairing ToryMPs send in their letters and the party stumbles into a vote on Mrs May’s future. One of those involved in discussions about whether to try to remove Mrs May tells me the Brexit ultras “are not as organised as you might think”.If there was a confidence vote, Mrs May would probably survive it. But after this week, it would be closer than it would have been before.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
