title: blaming all jews israel is wrong
story: Yes, I sympathise with those who were made homeless when Israel was created but I’ve never thought that because of this, I should set fire to Mr Bernstein’s bagel shop. Because that would be a stupid thing to do.I don’t much hold with how the Vatican dealt with the industrial-strength paedophilia, but that doesn’t mean I should cut up my Catholic girlfriend’s clothes.Putin is mad but I have Russian friends. Trump is an a**e but I still fancy Taylor Swt. Assad is evil but one of the most enjoyable evenings I’ve ever spent was with Syrian people in Damascus.This is what the Labour Party seems to be incapable of grasping. That you can have issues with Israel’s behaviour over the past  years and its intransigence now.But that there’s a world of dference between a state in the Middle East that must fight for its survival, and Mr Gruber, the Jewish antique dealer in the Paddington stories.You can’t hurt him because of all the rocket attacks on the Gaza strip any more than you can hurt me because of what an Englishman did on his plantation in Jamaica back in .People are people. Some are very nice and some are very terrible and being Jewish or Catholic or English has nothing to do with it. I could convert to Judaism.It would mean having my foreskin cut off and promising not to eat another bacon sandwich, so it’s not going to happen. Butit did, would that make me fair game for Corbyn’s SS It probably would. Because I’d taken up salt beef sandwiches, they’d get it into their heads that I was obviously an Israeli army general. It’s daft. I mean, Cat Stevens is a Muslim. But that doesn’t mean, every time he warbles his way through Matthew And Son, that he’s about to explode.You don’t meet a Cambodian waiter and think: “Aha. You’re in the Khmer Rouge”, any more than you think when you meet an Argentinian that he must be a stone-throwing moron — actually, come to think of it, I do think that. But I know I’m in the wrong.Some Argies are great. They must be. It’s just that I haven’t met one yet.But whatever, somebody said to me last week that the Labour Party will win the next general election, and I’m genuinely appalled by that because evenCorbyn isn’t a truly horrible piece of work — and he is — his henchmen are not just amusing Trots and commies. They’re downright bloody dangerous.Every day, I open the newspaper and there’s nothing.I do hope they’re all right.FOLLOWING three separate and serious accidents on the M this week, we all know what’s coming next.A lot of high-pitched nasal whining from the nation’s speed camera enthusiasts, who’ll jump up and down and weep into their beakers of organic soil juice.And no one will have the gumption to explain that the most serious of the crashes was caused because a dithery octogenarian chose to drive his car and caravan the wrong way up the carriageway.And the only way you can prevent accidents like this from happening is to say to the nation’s elderly: “We don’t care how competent and fit you feel and we don’t care how much you need a car to get about. You can’t have a licence once you’re past . The end.”DRIVERS are being urged to open their car door with their left hand, which causes the body to twist and therefore makes it easier to check no bicycles are coming.Safety and health people say the cyclists slamming into just- opened car doors is becoming a serious problem. Many, apparently, have sustained bruising and grazes and hurty knees.Of course, there is another idea. Cyclists should slow down when passing a car and give it a wide berth.Or better still, accept that roads are for cars and leave the children’s toy at home.IT’S now pretty much certain that there’s enough gas trapped in the rocks under northern England to keep Britain warm for  years.THE men who appeared this week in a video, shooting a bull elephant in Namibia, have defended themselves.They say hunting like this brings much-needed revenue to what’s a poor area, that only two hunting licences are issued a year and that it is necessary once in a while to have a small cull of the bulls. It all sounds very reasonable.But the fact is that they had the shooting skills of Stevie Wonder. They were pumping bullets into the poor animal and it didn’t go down for an age. You see more clean kills than that in a Mexican drug lord’s cellar.And why not take the shot when the animal is on its own  Why take it when the animal is with its mates, all of whom were plainly upset by the hideous spectacle So, I’m sorry. While it may be necessary to kill the odd elephant – though I can’t for the le of me work out why – can the job be given to someone who knows what he’s doing.RUSSIA has tried on a couple of occasions to build a big mirror in space that would reflect some of the sun’s light on to a town during the night. That would mean street lights are no longer needed.They’ve never made it work but as it sounds like a good idea, the Chinese have decided to give it a go.The mirror they’re creating will appear in the night sky like a bright star but, they say, it will give off just enough light for people to see where they’re going. Brilliant. Except for one small problem.The town on to which this heavenly torch will shine its light is Chengdu.And a small bit of research reveals that Chengdu is China’s Manchester. It’s foggy, cloudy or raining for  days of the year.I DID wonder why Bruce Springsteen decided to extend his Broadway show.I mean, he’s nearly , so why climb on stage every single night to tell the same old stories and sing the same old songs Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle prince harry invictus games opening ceremony sydney
story: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle dazzled crowds as they put on a loved-up display as they participated in proceedings at the Sydney Opera House.While the opening ceremony was hit with delays due to a tropical rain storm, the bad weather did not dampen spirits as Prince Harry took to the stage to mark the beginning of the games.Opening his remarks with a nod to his grandmother The Queen, the Duke said: On this day in , my grandmother, The Queen, stood in front of this Opera House and declared it open.Forty-five years later, to the day, it is my honour to be standing in front of this iconic symbol of Australias place in the modern world at the start of the fourth Invictus Games.He went on to encourage the competitors in an emotionally charged speech, before moving on to more personal matters.Prince Harry said: First of all, thank you for the welcome you have given Meghan and I over the last few days.I have been so proud to be able to introduce my we to you and we have been so happy to be able to celebrate the personal joy of our newest addition with you all.The pregnant Duchess looked stunning in a navy blue Stella McCartney dress and jacket ensemble, paired with ivory heels and a simple clutch bag.The coat has been designed by former X-Files star turned fashion designer, Gillian Anderson, who has created a capsule collection for designer label Winser London.A well coordinated Prince Harry looked dashing in a matching navy blue tie teamed with a grey tweed blazer and grey trousers.The parents-to-be were seen beaming with joy as they took their seats at the Opera House for the opening ceremony, with Meghan placing a tender hand on her husbands knee.They were seen sitting alongside Prime Minister Scott Morrison and NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian.The start of the Opening Ceremony was hit with delays following an intense thunderstorm over the New South Wales area.Despite the downpours and early hiccups, organisers were adamant that the day would go ahead as planned.An Invictus Sydney statement read: Organisers put an emergency plan in place, closing the site and forcing hundreds of spectators to run for cover.The thunderstorm over Sydney may have an impact on the Opening Ceremony #IG.The most important thing is to ensure everyones safety. The ceremony is scheduled for pm AEDT More updates to come.It was then later confirmed that the ceremony would go ahead as planned.The games were officially opened following an hours delay, with  athletes from  nations set to take part in the competition.The Invictus Games are an international Paralympic-style sporting event for wounded, sick or injured members of the armed forces, as well as veterans.The week-long event will see  competitors from  nations competing against one another in  dferent sports.Prince Harry created the games after being inspired by the US Warrior Games, a similar sporting event for injured service personnel.Sporting events at the games include wheelchair basketball, sitting volleyball and indoor rowing, and the events tend to attract a crowd packed with politicians and royals.The first ever Invictus Games took place in March  at the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park in London, United Kingdom.In Latin, Invictus means unconquered or undefeated, capturing the spirit of the injured services personnel who take part.The games also hold a very signicant place in the Duke and Duchess relationship, as it was where they went public about their romance last year.At last years Toronto games, Meghan and Harry put on a united front and opted for a black shirt with the emblem of the Games, in a display of love that caught the worlds attention.The  games have fallen in the middle of Prince Harry and Meghan Markles first overseas tour as a married couple.They are expected to watch some events over the coming days, before ing to Sydney for the closing ceremony on October .Earlier in the day, the couple paid tribute to Australia and New Zealands war dead as Harry unveiled an extension to the Anzac memorial at a sombre ceremony in Sydneys Hyde Park.Prince Harry, wearing his Blues  Royals tropical dress, medals and Knight Commander of the Victorian Order, also sported the insignia of his new position as the Queens personal aide-de-camp for the occasion.The -year-old Duke was joined by Meghan, in a black Emilia Wickstead dress and black Philip Treacy hat.The memorial commemorates those who fell in the First World War, as well as conflicts in Korea, Afghanistan, Iraq and the Colonial Wars.Governor General David Hurley welcomed the couple to the monument, where Harry formally opened the new £ million centenary wing underneath the main memorial.The former British army captain and his we laid a wreath of Australian native flowers at the steps of the memorial, as Prime Minister Scott Morrison, other dignitaries, and service men and women looked on.In a handwritten signed note pinned to the wreath, Harry wrote, In memory of those who paid the ultimate sacrice and in recognition of the men and women for whom the scars endure.Wearing the tropical dress of his regiment, the Blues and Royals, Harry unveiled a plaque that noted the extension was opened by a grandson of the Queen.The wording was a nod to the original plaque Prince Henry unveiled  years ago, which noted that the memorial was opened by the son of a king.Harry and Meghan were then taken on a tour of the newly remodelled shrine, which was first opened in  by Harrys great-great uncle, Prince Henry, the Duke of Gloucester, but was left incomplete due to a shortage of funds during the Great Depression.Here they were treated to a traditional Welcome to Country ceremony by two Aboriginal men.Robert Canning, , of the Gumbaynggirr people, greeted the couple with a didgeridoo performance.He said: Were doing a smoking ceremony to get rid of bad spirits and bring in good spirits and welcome everyone.It was very nice to meet the royals - I just hope they enjoyed my didgeridoo playing.Twins Krystal and Sienna Dawson presented the royal couple with a medallion and a painting during the visit.The girls, aged nine, are from the Koomurri Aboriginal Dance Troupe and both said they were nervous about meeting and performing for Harry and Meghan.Krystal, who did an Aboriginal art floral painting, said: They said hi and nice to meet you.The medallion, presented by Sienna, said play the game, the motto of the Beverly Hills public school which they attend.Following the unveiling of the memorial, Harry and Meghan headed off to Sydneys Cockatoo Island for the activities around the Invictus Games.When they arrived, Harry put an affectionate hand on his we’s lower back as they walked along the jetty to meet with the competitors and their support staff.The couple have spent their fth day playing games with participants and children at Cockatoo IslandThe pair were dressed casually, with husband and we wearing Invictus Games shirts.While the Duke chose to remain casual with a pair of chinos and brown shoes, Meghan brought a touch of glamour to the sporty afternoon by completing her look with a white blazer and some low-heeled black shoes.They then watched the races get under way before awarding the drivers with their well-deserved medals.The royal couple also spent some time playing with remote control cars with children who had travelled to the event from around the world with the athletes.Harry appeared to enjoy the toys as much as the kids as he was pictured laughing and even feigning annoyance as he gestured his arms in frustration.

title: jollibee london asian kfc chicken joy
story: Over a thousand people queued around the block in Earls Court to be among the first to get a taste of some of the unusual dishes served up.The two men at the front of the line had been waiting  hours for the restaurant to open at am today.The popular chain has been described as the Asian KFC.Jollibees signature dish is the Chickenjoy which is a piece of fried chicken and a side of spaghetti, smothered in a tomato sauce, and then topped with hotdog slices and ground beef.The dish is on sale in the UK for £..Also on the menu in Britain, which is slightly dferent from the one in Asia, is the Chickenjoy Bucket.This has either six or eight pieces of fried chicken, a Double Yumburger as well as fries, sweetcorn and ice-cream.Michael Sibson, , cleaner and balloon artist from Guildford in Surrey, was the first super fan in the queue and the first to step through the doors.He said: Im here because I miss Jollibee. Its been almost nine years since I last visited.My daughter is seven years old and when I told her it was going to open here, it was her dream that Id be the first person in the queue, and I wanted to make her dreams come true.”Super fan Mars El Brogy, , from West London, grew up in the Philippines and has lived in the UK for the past two years.She said: “Jollibee’s arrival is definitely on par with the level of happiness when I graduated, got my first job, got engaged, got married, had my kids… this is huge.”To celebrate the milestone of arriving on UK shores, Jollibee offered the first  customers free Chickenjoy meals to celebrate the first ever ‘National Chickenjoy Day’.Jollibee also has its own mascot like Ronald McDonald and Colonel Sanders – a giant red bumblebee.While the chain is massively popular in Asia and boasts , branches worldwide, the London outlet is only the second to open in Europe, with the Milan branch launching earlier this year.Dennis Flores, President and Head of Jollibee International Business for EMEAA said: “Arriving in the UK is a signicant milestone for our brand.We knew excitement was high among Filipinos and locals alike.We are even more thrilled with the level of buzz and excitement from the wider London community who have been queuing in their thousands to experience Jollibee for the first time.We’re looking forward to spreading the joy of eating and establishing ourselves as a part of the local food scene in London.”It has proved to be particularly successful in Vietnam and China.The chain plans to open another  stores in the UK and  across Europe over the next five years.Jollibee is owned by the Jollibee Foods Corporation, which is based in Manila and valued at .billion .

title: transformation teenager face tumour surgery italy
story: Stunning before and after pictures show Kambou Sie’s transformation following surgery in Italy that reconstructed part of his face and eradicated the cancer.The teenager from Ivory Coast, known as Prosper, was -years-old when the cancer started to attack his face.At , he had been robbed of his sight, he was struggling to breathe and his mother and the community he lived in had abandoned him.The only person who supported him was his father.He contacted Sister Claudine from the Liliane Foundation asking for someone to help his son.They passed his case onto the Italian charity A Voice For Padre Pio who made an appeal video and flew him out to Naples.After arriving at Naples Pascale Hospital in Italy  months ago, tests revealed that the tumour was a rare form of cancer called Burkitt lymphoma, which attacks the immune system.Prosper said: “When I arrived here, often I was afraid. I think that fear was all I felt. My nose used to block my sight. I had to hold my nose down to be able to see.”Villagers in his hometown Bondoukou had thought he was cursed and avoided him.“People said I was some kind of monster,” he said. “Saying that maybe it was something I had eaten which made me like this, but my cheeks just kept getting bigger and bigger.He underwent six months of chemotherapy, radiotherapy and stem cell replacement last year.He said: “Three days after I began chemo I realised I didn’t need to hold my nose down anymore to see.“I am very happy because when I go out I don’t cry. I am happy to meet people. I go out, I have fun, I play around. I have no problems. I am very happy.”Doctors are working on reconstructing his face since they eradicated the cancer.Specialist Dr Franc Ionna said: “There’s a flaw in the development of the facial bones. He has an alteration of the facial bone.“There’s a dissymmetry the left side is dferent to the right. One side has too much bone on the other is a deficit.”Prosper’s bones are still recovering from the impact of radiotherapy.The surgeon spent three hours emoving the cancer-damaged skin and releasing scar tissue hardened by the radiotherapy.Dr Ionna said: “I had an endless series of dficulties due to him having gone through radiotherapy the tissues were very stf just like a wall.”Prosper ed to his home in the Ivory Coast three weeks after his surgery.He is no longer shunned by the community and his mother.Burkitt lymphoma is a form of non-Hodgkins lymphoma in which cancer starts in the immune cells.It is named after British surgeon Denis Burkitt, who first identied the disease in  among children in Africa.It is common in young children who have malaria and Epstein-Barr virus, a common virus that also causes glandular fever.It occurs when the bodys immune cells start attacking itself.Burkitt lymphoma is uncommon – about  people are diagnosed with this type of lymphoma every year in the UK.The most common symptom is one or more lumps that develop quickly.It is the fastest growing human tumour and is fatalleft untreated.But intensive chemotherapy can improve survival rates.As treatment is intense patients are likely to need to stay in hospital while undergoing treatment.Prosper said: “My face has changed. It’s not finished, but it’s changed. I have also changed. I am not like before.“Before leaving, I couldn’t see a thing. It’s my country, but today as I arrive I’m new to it. I now have eyes to see it all. I dont know what to expect. How the welcome will be. I don’t knowthe welcome will be good or not. We’re arriving, it’s here.“After the new year, I’ll go to school to study and find out what I want to do in the future.”The teen willto Italy for more surgery in the future.His story will be shown on TLCs Body Bizarre, Saturdays at pm.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: peoples vote march westminster brexit referendum london
story: The Peoples Vote March set off from Park Lane at midday and will end in a rally in Parliament Square.Organisers initially claimed around half a million people took part but later revised that figure upwards to ,.London Mayor Sadiq Khan and celebrity chef Delia Smith are among those due to speak at the event.He told Sky News: “I can’t think of anything more democratic or British than trusting the British people.“Some of the promises made two years ago have not materialised. It is a scandal and it should not be accepted.Voters will neither forgive nor forget allow this miserable Brexit to proceed without people being given the final say.Simon Chater is part of the Devon another public vote on the issue.Britain is scheduled to leave the EU on March , but negotiations have been plagued by disagreements, particularly over the issue of the Republic of Ireland-Northern Ireland border, which will be the U.K.s only land frontier with the EU after Brexit. There are growing fears of a no-deal exit, which could create chaos at the borders and in the economy.Explaining the reason for the march, the group said: Whether you voted leave or remain, nobody voted to make this country worse off, to harm jobs, to damage the NHS, to affect the future of millions of young people, or to make this country more ided.The more the shape of the final Brexit deal becomes clear, the more it is clear that it will do nothing to improve social justice, reduce inequality, increase our standard of living, or create a better future for future generations.We are demanding our democratic voice be heard on Brexit. Since the referendum in , new evidence has emerged on what we were once told would be “the easiest deal in history”.

title: black panther scotland ayrshire sighting
story: Cops and animal experts were put on high alert yesterday after reports of a big cat on the prowl in Ayrshire.Villagers were left spooked by reports a lethal animal is on the loose.Stunned residents feared kids could be attacked amid claims a huge beast was spotted prowling in fields.And police initially feared a panther was roaming villages.Last night locals were still on edge despite animal experts later casting doubt.The pic comes amid a hoax sighting created by a teenager joker.The prankster caused more panic after creating a panther out of metal and sticking it in a nearby field.Robbie Brown, , crafted the big cat with a laser cutter before posting snaps of his replica on social media.The welder received hundreds of shares with locals believing it was the real deal — one user even called the cops to report the sighting.Robbie, of Sinclairston near where the animal was spotted, said: “I just did it for a laugh.“Everyone was talking about the other sighting so I spent ten minutes crafting one out of metal.“It got a crazy reaction on Facebook, and some people thought it was real.“Others realised it was fake because the tail was in the same position in every picture. It’s been a good laugh.”Police sources last night confirmed they had one call from a member of the public about the hoax creation.Meanwhile an online joker has created a fake account on social media for the panther.Tweeting under Black Cat Fae Drongan, it’s attracted hundreds of followers.

title: maps world wrong scientist claims
story: A Met Office scientist has compiled the map using official data - and the US and Russia appear much smaller.According to Neil R Kayes map, Africa is three times the size of the two countries in the two-dimensional representation, while Scandinavia is dwarfed by India.The current most common map of the world is the Mercator projection which was created in  to help sailors navigate - but there are some discrepancies with the map.According to Mercator, Greenland and Africa appear roughly the same size, while Alaska seems larger than the US and Antarctica also seems much larger than all the continents.However, in the map by Mr Kaye - a climate data scientist at Met Office - countries near the northern hemisphere appear smaller than previous representations.The map was created by inputting Met Office data into Ggplot, a data visualisation package for statistical programming, Mr Kaye said.He said he then used a stereographic projection - a particular mapping that projects a sphere onto a plane - centred at the latitude and longitude at the centre of each country to create the final map.On Twitter Mr Kaye said: Each country is projected to the spherical projection and placed at the centre of where it appears in the Natural Earth projection.There was then some manual tweaking of countries that are closer to the poles.On the mosaic map, Greenland appears much smaller than Africa while Scandinavias landmass is also considerably smaller than India.Antarctica also appears to be slightly larger than Australia - a complete contrast to previous demonstrations.

title: peoples vote march against brexit
story: NewsPeoples Vote march against Brexit sees more than , bring streets to standstillThousands of anti-Brexit campaigners are marching through the capital demanding a second referendumShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorCharlotte Neal:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video demonstrators-line-streets-london-peoples-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEnormous crowds are swelling through central London as anti-Brexit campaigners demand a second referendum. The Peoples Vote March set off from Park Lane at midday and will end in a rally in Parliament Square. Aerial footage on Sky News showed tens of thousands of people making their way through the capital - organisers now claim , are taking part after originally saying ,. Green Park Tube stations entrance was forced to close as tens of thousands of protesters, their kids and their dogs thronged past the Ritz Hotel towards Trafalgar Square. Draped in EU flags, they chanted b******s to Brexit and Peoples Vote as they were led by brass groups, a samba band, a woman shaking tambourines and a Theresa May drag queen.  Placards branded Boris Johnson a w***er, c**kwomble, liar and a c*** while others declared F**k Farage, Brexsh**, Lies wreck lives and also stop fracking you c***s. One proclaimed Theresa May is a reptile while another simply showed Tory Brexiteer Jacob Rees Mogg in a top hat with the word LOL. Others declared Brexit is a death cult and Brexit is borderline insanity - showing a map of Northern Ireland. Racist a***holes should stay in Nigel Farages pants and not voting booths, said another. Organisers faced an angry backlash online after an official bus was pictured carrying a placard that said: UK now in so much trouble government appointed suicide minister. Dont top yourself. Another placard declared: Hitler would be proud of this Brexit, with the X replaced by a swastika. Director of communications for Peoples Vote, Tom Baldwin, tweeted: This is not anything authorised by the Peoples Vote campaign. Nor would it be, because it is completely inappropriate. Elsewhere, demonstrations are also taking place in Manchester with police saying an EDL protest and counter campaign is also under way. In a statement released prior to the march, organisers said the campaign would use the biggest, loudest and most important demonstration on Brexit to unleash a postal tidal wave on MPs in Parliament.  The crowd was told it is time to send MPs the message that they will not be forgiventhey allow a bad deal to be rammed through Parliament or blind-fold the public about Brexits long-term costs. The march is part of the #WriteThisWrong campaign, in which , postcards will be distributed with the words Brexit has already become a dog’s dinner – the whole process is going badly wrong. And it’s only going to get worse. It was planned to be led by , young people in pink T-shirts from across the country. But so crowded was the march that they ended up almost an hour behind the front of the column of protesters.  The rally at Parliament Square was due to begin at .pm, but by .pm the tail end of the march was only just flowing through Piccadilly. A giant banner declaring stop Tory Brexit had to be carried by  people. Others proclaimed Pulling out never works and Brexit is Raabish - mocking the Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab. And a woman pushed her baby in a pram that bore the slogan: Literally crapping myself about Brexit. London Mayor Sadiq Khan and celebrity chef Delia Smith are among those who spoke at the event, along with MPs from Labour, Conservative, Liberal Democrat, Green Party, the SNP and Plaid Cymru. Mayor of London Mr Khan, speaking ahead of his  appearance, said: Today will go down as an historic moment in our democracy. A moment when in their thousands, people from every corner of our country and every section of our society will take to the streets - coming to make our voice heard.  Weve heard some complain that a public vote would be undemocratic and unpatriotic. But the opposite is true. Theres nothing more democratic - nothing more British - than trusting the people to have the final say on our future. The lies, the mistruths and the deceptions of the referendum campaign have now been exposed, and its clear the will of the people is changing. No one voted to leave the EU to make themselves poorer. No one voted to make le harder for our children and grandchildren. No one voted to see our NHS damaged. And no one voted for the shambles that this Government has created. Emma Stevens and Emily Longman are two of the students leading the march behind a Peoples Vote banner. Miss Longman, , said she was four months too young to vote in the referendum. She said: Were both Spanish students due to study abroad next year, but no one knows what will happen with Erasmus funding. Miss Stevens, also , said: We dont want the other European countries to hold the same view [of leaving the EU]. Marchers will be encouraged to write a personal message on the other side of the postcard and address it to their MP before handing them to People’s Vote volunteers for delivery direct to the House of Commons next week.  The campaign will also launch an innovative new email tool, integrated into the People’s Vote website, where people can put in their postcodes to find their MP and write personalised text to their elected representatives. A leading campaigner for the Peoples Vote, Andrew Adonis, said: Brexit becoming a dog’s dinner. This week’s fresh chaos and confusion over Brexit negotiations has exposed how even the best deal now available will be a bad one for Britain. It’s a mess that nobody voted for and the reason we’re in such a growing crisis is that those cheerleading for Brexit know the promises they made can never be kept.  So this campaign is about using the people power writing to their MP get a People’s Vote to address the wrongs of this botched Brexit process. This is about making sure MPs understand how strong feelings are running on this vital issue. If they are wavering, they need to know there is a political price to be paid for doing the wrong thing. Voters will neither forgive nor forgetMPs allow this miserable Brexit to proceed without people being given the final say. Simon Chater is part of the Devon for Europe group, which arranged eight coaches to bring campaigners to London for the event. The -year-old from South Devon said: This is the first time in my le Ive been political. He said  people had travelled in coaches arranged by the group, with some leaving Devon at am.  Carmen Smith, a For our Futures Sake Supporter from Wales, who is due to speak at the event, said: Today will see a vast march and rally of people from every corner of the country and all walks of le demanding their right to have the final say on Brexit. The People’s Vote March for The Future is going to be the biggest and loudest demonstration on Brexit yet. The biggest problems are still to be negotiated, many of the consequences are still being concealed and,we carry on like this, the arguments will never end. That’s why the People’s Vote March for the Future will be led by thousands of young people – students, apprentices and everyone starting out in le – whose voices have too often been ignored. Democracy means you don’t have to accept this. Time is short. The issue is urgent. The Brexit Elite has shown they can’t sort it out. But you can – by demanding a People’s Vote. Joe Trickey, from Croydon, is celebrating his rd birthday at the march. He said: I believe very strongly in the EU as a place of peace and strength. Going out puts us in isolation and leaving isnt about trade deals, its about our values. title: i adopted dad now ive
story: NewsI was adopted and so was my dad and now Ive adopted says father whose amazing adoptive family spans three generationsMark Mulley was a adopted as a child by dad Ivan who it transpired was himself adopted and now two children have a new home thanks to the family Mark createdShareCommentsByAmanda Killelea:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMark Mulley with his adoptive parents "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWatching his two boys wake up with the biggest smiles on their faces, Mark Mulley knows that adopting them was the best decision he and we Deb ever made. Jack, five, and Thomas,  months, both have cerebral palsy and require extra care and attention, but Mark and Deb shower them with all the love and support they could possibly need. As soon as Deb tentatively suggested adopting children with special needs to Mark he didn’t hesitate. And that is despite his own experience of adoption when he struggled through his teenage years desperately wondering why his birth mother had given him up.  Mark, , explains: “I have always known I was adopted, there was never a time that it was dropped as a bombshell. I later found out that my dad had been adopted too, but he never spoke about it at all. “But I was going through a period of questioning everything - why was I adopted  How could someone carry a baby for nine months and give it away  It was the rejection mentality - I’d only just been born and she didn’t want me. When Mark got to the age of  he knew he had to find out his birth family history and approached social services. When he read the file he discovered his birth mum was only  when he had him and had decided she couldn’t give him the le that she felt he deserved and had no option but to have him adopted. He said: “Reading that, and reading the letters between her and her social worker, and that her mother was begging the social workers to talk her out of it, that completely changed my view of myself.  “Instead of thinking what was wrong with me for her to give me up, it became she put me first - she gave me up to give me the best chance in le regardless of how she felt. What a sacrice she made for me. That was absolutely true love. It changed who I was overnight - somebody loved me so much to give me a decent start I had to make the most of it.” But Mark still felt her had to keep his news to himself and didnt tell his adoptive parents. Even when he traced his birth mum and started to build a relationship with her, he didn’t say a word. He sent a letter to his birth mum’s last known address and miraculously her brother still lived there and passed the letter on. Then  years after she gave her much-loved son up for adoption, mum Melita finally saw him again. Mark says: “When she opened the door and I looked at someone who actually looked like me for the first time in my le was amazing. We just hugged for what seemed like forever.” Mark, from Cheltenham, discovered he had a half-brother two years younger than him, and when Melita, , married her long-term partner Mark drove her to the wedding and was a witness, and was also best man at his half brother’s wedding.  But he still hadn’t told his birth parents Ivan and Jean Mulley. He says: “At first I didn’t want to tell them in case nothing came of it, but then the longer it went on the harder it was to say anything.” Unfortunately his dad passed away in  without ever knowing that Mark, , had found his birth mum. And it was only when he and Deb, , started their own adoption journey that they were advised by experts that he needed to tell his adoptive mum that he was in contact with his birth mum. “It was hard telling her,” says Mark. “I explained to her that she was my mum, she would always be my mum and nothing would change.” Eventually Jean and Melita met for the first time -with Jean bringing pictures of Mark from throughout his le to show Melita how her little baby boy had grown. Mark said: “It was so lovely to see them walking along together, arm in arm, chatting away. Unfortunately that was the only time they met. My mum passed away in  but she knew everything and was happy about the situation.” Having been through all that, Mark, a chaplain at a dementia care centre, was perfectly placed to become an adoptive parent himself. We Deb, , had always wanted to adopt from being a little girl. Both of them had worked with people with disabilities and felt they could give a child with additional needs a great le. “Debs has got experience and expertise on additional needs, I have got the adoption experience. We work together as a team,” says Mark. Speaking about their boys, Mark’s voice fills with pride. “Both boys are wonderful, they are so positive and happy,” he smiles. “Our oldest boy uses a wheelchair, and he has just blossomed.  He settled in with us straight away and is absolutely bright as a button. “He can’t verbally communicate well and his words are dficult to understandyou don’t know him, which is frustrating for him - you can see him give us an exasperated look when we ask him to repeat himself and when we finally get it he gives us a big cheer. He is always one step ahead of us and his memory is amazing. “Our youngest boy has been with us since June. He can almost sit on his own, they don’t know whether he will be likely to walk or not, the physio is assessing him. But he has already surpassed all his predictions. We were told he was likely to be blind, but he can see well. They said he would never cope with cuddles and being touched, but he loves cuddles. “They have to prepare you for the worst, but he is doing incredibly well. Becoming their parents is absolutely the best thing we have ever done. And adopting more children in the future is more than a possibility for us.

title: coca cola addict mum three
story: NewsCoca Cola addict mum-of-three drank EIGHT cans a day for  years until she became anaemicBecky Dean said she has now convinced herself the fizzy drink doesnt actually taste as good as she thoughtShareCommentsByAlex GroveClaire Gilbody-Dickerson:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe mum-of-three has spoken out about her addiction to Coca Cola "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-three drank eight cans of Coca Cola every day for  years. Becky Deans obsession with the sugary treat started when she first had a taste of the fizzy drink at the age of . She revealed how she would have a can as soon as she woke up and would carry on throughout the day. The mum was forced to minimise the intake of her favourite sugar-filled drink when she started fainting on her way to work and was diagnosed with aneamia. “It was always my go-to drink and it would literally be the only thing I would drink,” the -year-old said.  “I would need it the minute I got up and then one between breakfast and dinner. “Then, I would have one with dinner and I would always have a bottle with me at work. I used to buy a -pack from the supermarket which I would get through within a week and I was drinking maybe eight cans a day at most. “I made a joke about it even though people would say to me, ‘you should start drinking something ’. But I had been drinking it for so long I found it was the only thing I could sip.” In spite of this, Ms Dean was still hooked by the fizzy diet drink and it took her another five years to finally tackle her crippling habit.  “It was great to drink in terms of it being low in calories but it was still having an effect on my teeth, for example. Earlier this year, Ms Dean found herself fainting on the way to work and tests discovered she was anaemic. Doctors advised her to look at making several lestyle changes, including cutting down her Coca Cola consumption. She then made a drastic decision by going cold turkey. “I recently found out I was anaemic and there was a couple of times where I had fainted en route to work, she said. I was always tired and as I was in the middle of making health changes anyway, so I thought this was something I could cut out.” To put her addiction to the test, Ms Dean went the whole month of September without drinking a single can of Coke - much to the surprise of her friends and family.  She motivated herself by deciding to donate the money she saved from not buying Coke to the NSPCC. But it was not an easy challenge. She stocked up on a “multitude” of other drinks, including smoothies, juices, flavoured water and cups of tea, and gave all her remaining Coke Zero cans to her partner Sean Rouen.“I found it really hard,” Ms Dean said. “It was super hard and I felt like I was getting more headaches and for the first week feeling even more tired too without Coke.“I found a nice flavoured water which was infused with cucumber and another infused with jasmine. Those were nice, cold and refreshing and I used them as substitutes for my thirst for Coke Zero.” After  long days, Ms Dean managed to complete the fundraiser and for the first time in almost  years she was able to abstain from drinking Coke.  However, rather than eliminate Coke from her le completely, the mum decided to cut down her consumption and drink it in moderation going forward. “I knew after that month there was no way I could go back to the amount I was drinking. I don’t gulp cans like I used to and there have been some days where I’ve just had a small can with my tea. “It has not taken over - I won’t let it, and I’ve convinced myself it doesn’t taste as good as what it used to.” She said: “Picking a charity spurred me on and the thought of the money going to someone  was more of an incentive. “I knew I was never going to give it up for le because that is unachievable. But I needed to do something drastic and set myself a strict challenge with a start date and finish date, and this was it.” What Coca-Cola says  Coca-Cola has always denied that either the caffeine or the sugar in its drinks are addictive. There are mg of caffeine in a ml can of Coca-Cola, compared with ml in a mug of instant coffee. Speaking to Thein , the multinational firm said the company has used caffeine as a “safe ingredient” for more than  years in its product. It added that people who are “addicted to sugar” are not being scientically robust. Coca-Cola has been contacted for an additional comment in response to Ms Dean’s story. You can donate to her fundraising page by clicking here.

title: i lashed out doctors asked
story: NewsI lashed out when doctors asked for my mums organs - but  years later I know she saved six livesThe Mirrors Change the Law for Le campaign inspired writer Rhian Lubin to find out how her familys decision to donate her mums organs in  saved the lives of six peopleShareCommentsByRhian Lubin:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsRhian Lubins mum Heulwen was an organ donor who saved  lives "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen the doctors asked us about donating my mum’s organs, all I could feel was fury. I was aged , and hours earlier we’d been told my mum, Heulwen, had suffered a brain aneurysm and was only being kept alive by a le support machine. It was the most painful moment of my le. The doctors were trying to be patient and thoughtful, but there was urgency to their request they couldn’t mask. I remember one saying: “We know what a dficult time this is for you. We’re very sorry, but we need to discuss whether you will agree to donating Heulwen’s organs.” I didn’t completely understand, possibly because of my age, but I did know it felt like they were physically ripping my heart out. I lashed out, horried they were even asking us the question so soon, at such a sensitive time but now I know they were just doing their job. Much of the rest of the conversation is a blur, but as a family my grandad Gordon, now , dad Simon, , uncle Hywel, , my sisters Hanna, , Beth, , and I decided that, yes, we should donate.  My  year-old mum was not on the organ donation register, but she’d happened to tell my uncle six months earlier that she would like to be a donorthe time ever came. I’m sure she didn’t think that time would come so very soon. We had to say goodbye then. I gave her a final hug, and remember she was so warm, while at the same time I knew she wasn’t really there anymore. Then we left the hospital and as soon as I got home, I instantly got changed and binned the clothes I’d been wearing for the last  hours. Le slowly limped on but I didn’t think about organ donation again, instead choosing to block out the memory of that terrible day in January . But when the Mirror launched the Change the Law for Le campaign in , calling for everyone in the UK to be a potential organ donor unless they choose to opt out, I began to wonder about the people who might have benefitted from my mum’s donation. Were the operations even successful or was it all a waste of time  Was it just one person  Did they have children  Was it a child who was helped  So I decided to write to the NHS donor family care service.  I wasn’t feeling particularly optimistic that I’d be able to find anything out, yet within three days they sent me letters from  addressed to my dad and to me that I’d never seen before - because at the time I just didn’t want to know. It took me a week to prepare myself to read the letters and then it was on a train to Wales, aptly, because that’s where my mum was from, that I decided to open them. Incredibly the letters told me my mum saved six people’s lives. Thanks to her four other mums and a man in his fties had been given le-saving transplants. Her liver was given to a -year-old mum-of-three and one of her kidneys was given to a -year-old single mum with a young daughter. Before the transplant, this mum had been on dialysis for many years and could now spend more time with her little girl. My mum’s second kidney was donated to a -year-old woman who lives with her son, daughter and own mother. She too was confined to a le on dialysis before the transplant.  A -year-old man was given one of my mum’s lungs, and without it he would have died. Before this, he was living alone and struggling to cope on his own at home. The second lung was given to a -year-old woman, married and with two grown up children. But it was a letter dated two months later that touched me the most. Dated March , , it said: “A few weeks ago a five-year-old boy underwent le saving surgery and was transplanted with one of Heulwen’s heart valves. “This little boy was born with severe heart problems and prior to his operation was very unwell. “We can only imagine the dference this operation will make to this boy’s le and to his family.” I now know a little bit of my mum lives on in those six people, something that will now comfort me forever. The immediate years after her death were the most dficult of my le. But I was carried through by the love and support of my family, especially my dad, my sisters, and and my friends. As we pulled each other through, there were still moments of light and laughter while we adapted to le without mum. One Sunday, two weeks after she died, we were remembering how good mum’s gravy was with the roast while dad tried to replicate her recipe. It ended up looking like hot chocolate, which he then accidentally spilt all over the kitchen. We all laughed and cried at the same time.  We remembered how my mum, an animal lover like me, would allow our pet guinea-pigs to run around our living room driving my dad mad. And my favourite memory of the short time I had with mum was just me and her, watching Corrie together. We got a golden retriever called Bruce, who was extremely disobedient but brought us so much happiness during that dark time, always comforting me when the grief would come. And my dad became both parents to three teenages girls. To my great embarrassment, he found it amusing to ask me very loudly over from the next aisle in the supermarket which tampons he should buy for us. My mum was born in Swansea, was very proud to be Welsh, and later went on to work as a speech therapist in St Albans, Hertfordshire, where I grew up. Her real passion was art and music, something she always tried to pass on to me and my sisters. We miss her everyday but are comforted by her incredible legacy. Changing the law to an opt-out system won’t make a death any less painful and, as I know only too well, families might feel outraged when they are asked to donate in that devastating moment. But this is why it’s so important to talk to your loved ones about organ donation andyou, like me, have decided to join the organ donor register. Change the Law for Le

title: remains 130000 year old woolly
story: NewsRemains of , year old woolly mammoth dug up by Highways England workers on ABones of a woolly rhino were also found by the Highways England crew and the ancient remains are set to be studied so their exact age can be determinedShareCommentsByAdam TheofilatosAbigail Rabbett:,  OCT NewsAn ancient rhino skull was also uncovered "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Road workers have dug up the remains of an ancient woolly mammoth believed to be , years old.The bones are thought to date back to the ice age and were uncovered by the highway crew working on the A expansion between Cambridge and Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire. This project has led to a number of historic discoveries.The latest finding was uncovered by Highways England workers, Cambridgeshire Live reports.And the patch of land near Fenstanton where the bones were discovered is believed to be an ancient river. Some remains of a woolly rhino were also found by the highway crew and the parts are set to undergo a study by specialists to determine their exact age.  A Highways England spokesman said: The remains of a woolly mammoth dating back to the ice age are among the latest remarkable finds from the team working on the A Cambridge to Huntingdon project. The woolly mammoth which was around the same size as an African Elephant roamed Eurasia thousands of years ago before its extinction. Its fur meant it was perfectly adapted to the cold environment during the last ice age. Mammoths, which are thought to have weighed up to eight tonnes, became extinct in around ,BC.Scientists believe their extinction was a result of climate change and being hunted by humans.Remains of the woolly mammoth have been found on most continents except for Australasia and South America.  The spokesman continued: Operatives also discovered the remains of a woolly rhino, both at least , years old, during excavations for construction materials near Fenstanton in what was once an ancient river. They are the latest in a series of fantastic finds from the team building the new road, with other remarkable discoveries including Prehistoric Henges, Iron Age settlements, Roman pottery kilns, three Anglo-Saxon villages, and a deserted medieval village. Palaeontologist Dean Lomax has labelled the discoveries as exciting and quite uncommon. He said: Woolly mammoth and woolly rhino were once a common part of the wildle here in the UK, during the Ice Age. We know this because their fossils have been found at ious fossil sites across the UK. However, recent discoveries like this are quite uncommon and it is exciting that they have been uncovered during road works. It would be interesting to discover whether this is a one-off discovery or whether more iniduals are preserved in the same area. It is also important that these specimens are appropriately cared for and conserved. These types of bone, especially mammoth tusk, can deteriorate quite poorlyleft untreated so great care should be taken with these remains. The pound.billion A project is due to open in December .

title: teenager 19 becomes mum dad
story: NewsTeenager, , becomes mum and dad to little brother, , after BOTH parents killed in two yearsEXCLUSIVE: Neighbours set up crowdfunding campaign to support Nathan who is in charge of caring for his brother Luke after dad died in bike crashShareCommentsByJoe Smith:,  OCT NewsBrothers Nathan and Luke went through a drastic change of relationship after losing both their parents "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn orphaned teenager has taken on the role of mum and dad to his younger brother after tragedy struck twice. Nathan Phillips, , and Luke, , lost their mum Anita to cancer in . She was . The boys and their devastated dad, David, pulled together. But further heartbreak was to come when, just three months ago, shymotorcyclist David, , died in a head-on collision with a truck. Luke was on the back of the bike and was severely injured. Part of his foot had to be amputated and David’s fate was kept from him as he battled for survival.  In that cruel moment, le changed forever for the brothers. Yet it has drawn them even closer together. And for Nathan there is no more partying or going out with his mates. He says: “I’ve got to focus on looking after Luke now. “When he was first in hospital we had to keep telling him Dad was okay.  “The doctors saidwe’d told him straight away he’d have panicked and he wouldn’t have been able to go into surgery. “His foot got stuck under the wheel of the lorry. He had to have half his big toe and all of his little toe amputated. “He lost a lot of the skin on his foot, he needed a skin graft from the top of his leg on to his foot.” The accident happened in Mancetter, Warwickshire – a few miles from the family’s Nuneaton home. Luke was left in a coma at Birmingham Children’s Hospital. And even after he came round Nathan was only able to tell him about their dad once he had stabilised.  He adds: “It was pretty hard seeing Luke like that. “He thought Dad was okay when he was in AE. We had to keep telling him it was all right. “Telling Luke that Dad died was the worst thing I’ve ever had to do.” As he stands beside Luke, Nathan vows to take on the role of mum and dad – as well as big brother. His love and sheer shydetermination to help Luke cope would make Anita and David proud.  Nathan has nursed Luke on the path to recovery while still grieving himself. He managed to get himself a better paid job – swapping pot-washing work for a position at Aldi. Then he got to grips with running a household – paying bills, doing the chores, looking after them both. Speaking for the first time, Nathan goes on: “I think it has taught me to make the most of every day, don’t let little things upset you and just enjoy the days as they come. “I don’t want to be upset or angry about losing Mum and Dad. I’ve got to focus on looking after Luke now. “We respect each other a lot more, I think. I have to do things like wake him up early for school – but he’s all right about it.  “He still gets his moments where he says ‘I miss Mum and Dad’ or ‘I wish Dad was here’ – you know, to give him a hug before bed. “But we do stuff together to make sure things work out.” Household chores have included redecorating their home. Nathan continues: “I used to spend more time with my mates. “I’d be out in my car all the time or on my Xbox. I can still do those things now – but not so much. “I’ve got the washing up, to do, the laundry, the shopping, making sure Luke’s unorm and my work stuff is sorted. I feel asI have been left to do everything by myself.  “It’s nobody’s fault, it’s just how the world is. “It has just meant I’ve had to mature a bit quicker. “Before losing my mum I had a normal le – no worries, going around doing my own thing, not having to worry about anyone but myself.” The brothers have fond memories of mum Anita, who was a sales assistant at Morrison’s.  And the pain is still raw after losing dad David, who worked as a CADoperator. But somehow, the tragic experience of the past two years has brought the brothers closer, Nathan says. He explains: “It has been tough now and then. Our relationship was always good but has grown dramatically since then. “He’s always been a good lad and never misbehaved. We argue now and again, but nothing serious.”  Despite the physical and psychological trauma, Nathan says Luke is doing well. He is back at school – in Year Eight – and is off his crutches. As for Nathan, he has given up the le of a typical -year-old. He says: “It’s just not an option. I work, I look after Luke and I see my girlfriend. “Sometimes me and my girlfriend will go outLuke’s at a friend’s house. I get a lot less time to myself.”  Nathan is Luke’s , but does get help from aunties and uncles. However, grandparents on both sides have passed away. After hearing their story the local community has rallied round, setting up a crowdfunding campaign and donating thousands to help the boys. Kindhearted friends and family set an initial target of pound,. But that has been surpassed and the total currently stands at pound,. Nathan is hugely appreciative. And every penny will be put to good use.  He says of the appeal: “It’s been brilliant, it’s going really well. “My next door neighbour Wayne did a sponsored bike ride and raised pound, from that. “It’ll make le easier. We want to do a few things to the house. “Decorating the house, moving bedrooms. “Hopefully we can make it a bit more homely for me and Luke.”To donate, visit: justgiving crowdfunding nathanlukephillips

title: tired driver mistakes live lane
story: News"Tired" driver stops in wrong lane for rest leading to horror motorway crashThe silver Ford Mondeo stopped in lane one where a black Volkswagen van ploughed into it from behind, say policeShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe driver of a Ford Mondeo thought the live lane was a hard shoulder, say police "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA driver is lucky to be alive after he was so tired he stopped for a rest in the wrong lane - resulting in a horror crash, according to police. Derbyshire Police were called to a crash on Saturday morning after the driver of a silver Ford Mondeo apparently mistook lane one of the M for the hard shoulder. He pulled over for a rest between junctions  and  - part of a smart motorway - near Mansfield, Notts., leading to a devastating crash with a black Volkswagen van. The impact was so severe that the Mondeo was knocked off the road.  Luckily, both drivers suffered only minor injuries - and the Mondeo driver was reported for careless driving. The lane was shut at .am to deal with the incident. Derbyshire Roads Policing Unit shared two photos on Twitter - one showing the crushed back end of the Mondeo and one showing the crumpled front end of the Volkswagen. The force tweeted: M NB J to J. One we dealt with this morning. Mondeo driver was so tired he mistook lane one of four to be the hard shoulder and decided to stop for a rest - here is the result. Minor injuries and Mondeo driver reported for careless driving.  Smart motorways are designed to actively manage the flow of traffic using monitoring and technology controlled by staff at a regional control centre. The hard shoulder is temporarily or permanently opened to traffic to increase capacity. Drivers are told to use marked refuge areas, which can be a mile or more apart,there is an emergency on a smart motorway without a hard shoulder, and put their hazard lights ontheir car breaks down. Staff can activate and change signs and speed limits in the event of congestion, a crash or debris. Englands smart motorways include stretches of the M, M and M. Highways England claim they improve journey reliability and prevent crashes. But groups including AA have raised concerns with the government, with a recent poll of drivers revealing eight in  think the removal of hard shoulders on smart motorways has made them more dangerous. Some drivers have called the lay-bys on smart motorways death zones, and others refused to use the old hard shoulder because they fear hitting a broken down vehicle, the AA added. The RAC has also expressed concerns, saying: The removal of the hard shoulder fundamentally increases the risk to drivers who might suffer a breakdown and are unable to reach a refuge area. Highways England has pledged to install more emergency lay-bys.

story: NewsBrilliant map reveals how people pronounce scone across the UK - and its nearly as isive as BrexitWhether you pronounce scone like cone or gone has been hotly debatedShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  OCT News "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailScones are possibly the most quintessentially British baked goods you can get. Fluffy little cakes that can be fruity, cheesy or plain, served with jam, cream or just butter. Theyre great. But a debate still rages on in the UK about how to pronounce the word scone - and it seems we still have not reached a consensus. One person has created a fantastic map that illustrates the ongoing ide over the issue, tracking the spots where people say scone to rhyme with bone and those who say scone to rhyme with gone. Its fascinating to see where the isions lie.  Reddit user Bezzleford made the map using data collected by Cambridge University in , where researchers examined the pronunciation of the word across the UK and Ireland.Looking at the map, it appears the issue is nearly as isive among Brits as Brexit is.Swathes of the UK are yellow on the map, which means the area is split almost   on how to say the word. Most of Ireland and pockets of southern England and the midlands rhyme with cone whereas huge areas of the north and Scotland rhyme scone with gone.

story: NewsPrince Harry speaks about personal joy at Meghans pregnancy at Invictus Games opening ceremonyThe ceremony at Sydney Opera House comes as the royal parents-to-be embark on their royal tour of Australia, Tonga, New Zealand and FijiShareCommentsByRussell MyersCharlotte Neal:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror am celebrity-news video prince-harry-thanks-aussies-warm-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Harry has spoken of his and Meghan Markles personal joy as he gave a rousing speech at the opening ceremony of the Invictus Games. The Duke of Sussex managed to calm his apparent nerves to pay homage to the Invictus generation at the ceremony at Sydney Opera House. He honoured the one Invictus generation - service personnel, veterans and war dead. The duke thanked the hosts for the welcome and said he and Meghan are so happy to celebrate the personal joy of our newest addition with you all. He added that he was proud to introduce his we to them.  Harry, , said mental toughness is being honest about how we feel. He said: ​With the help of medical science,​ ​the Invictus generation has not only survived injuries that in past conflicts would have been fatal, but has also chosen to fight back from the darkest of places to be here tonight. They have shown us the true meaning of resilience. When they have been open about their hidden emotional and mental wounds, the Invictus generation has shown us that in today’s world being tough means being honest about how we feel - both inside and out. He later added: You are going to put on one hell of a show over the next week.  The grand opening got under way after being delayed by a tropical storm that rocked Sydney. Impressive lightning flashed overhead at the Opera House in the hour before the ceremony was due to start, as a storm brought eerie dark clouds, strong winds and heavy rain. Spectators were forced to flee for cover until it passed and Prince Harry admitted he was worried the ceremony would have to be cancelled. Technical equipment was damaged adding to the delay of the ceremony, according to organisers who were concerned about health and safety.  But the the heavy rain came to a sudden stop shortly before the couple were escorted into the venue by Premier of New South Wales Gladys Berejiklian. I was a bit worried, Prince Harry told the Premier as they walked across the room. Thankfully it looks like the sky is clearing now. Meghan, who was wearing a Stella McCartney dress and coat by X-Files actress Gillian Anderson for Winser London, smiled as the Premier told the couple there a lot of people looking forward to meeting you. Prince Harry was pictured practising his speech hours before the ceremony on stage in front of we Meghan Markle as dark clouds swirled overhead. He then appeared nervous as the royal couple took their seats ahead of the ceremony, while a lively Meghan chatted to her neighbour.  Created by Prince Harry, the Invictus Games is an international sporting event for injured or sick service personnel and veterans from  nations. The opening ceremony started an hour late - at .pm local time- following the storm. Crowds gave a huge cheer for the duke and duchess as the ceremony began, said Russell Myers, the Mirrors royal correspondent. Sydney Opera House earlier said the weather would not stop the opening ceremony from taking place. In a series of tweets, it said: Tonights Invictus Opening Ceremony is a signicant event for everyone involved but particularly for the competitors and their accompanying family and friends who have been looking forward to being on the forecourt of the Sydney Opera House for a fabulous Aussie welcome.  The Duke and Duchess of Sussex - currently a third of the way through a -day tour of Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand - attended a reception ahead of the ceremony at the opera houses famous Bennelong Restaurant earlier today. They were joined there by competitors and their families, as well as New South Wales premier Gladys Berejiklian and Olympic swimmer Ian Thorpe OAM , who acted as Master of Ceremonies. Political figures, Invictus ambassadors and even royalty had gathered to meet the couple. Jordan’s Princess Dina Mired and Prince Mired bin Ra’ad were among guests who had broken into small groups to meet the Sussexes during their short visit. Invictus friends and family ambassador Leesa Kwok, , gted the duchess a small knitted yellow flower when they met.  This is so beautul, she remarked. Kwok, whose husband Jamie Tanner is competing for Australia in the wheelchair rugby and tennis events, told Meghan how , of the hand-knitted were made especially for the games by a group of elderly war widows from Aged Care . Meghan was really touched by the story and said the flower was really pretty, said Kwok. I had actually met them both last year in Toronto and gave one of the flowers and he asked ‘Can I have another one for my gran ’ so it was lovely to share a third one with his we. The flowers are made as a show of support to the friends, family and close supporters - it’s something for them to wear and show their pride.  Meghan was interested to hear the backstory. She has this amazing ability to connect and make you feel like you’re the only person in the room. We also spoke about the impact that Invictus Games has had not just on the lives of those competing but the friends and families who stick by during dficult times. When I was telling Meghan she stopped and said, ‘Hold on, I want my husband to hear this too’. They’re both so lovely, so caring. In the event of severe weather for the Opening Ceremony plans are in place to relocate people under cover until it is safe for them to resume their seats.  Earlier in the day Kwok’s son Danyan Jones had raced a remote control truck against Harry at Cockatoo Island during the Jaguar Land Rover Driving Challenge event. Harry was pleased to hear he would be wearing his medal to the opening ceremony, added Kwok. Prince Harry had a laugh with Olympic gold cyclist and Invictus Ambassador Anna Meares when she showed him a newspaper article from  when she beat Britain’s Victoria Pendleton in the  Olympic Games. There is a photo of Harry with his head in his hands the moment I won the cycling event and we had a good laugh about it, says -year-old Meares. I’d actually started by chatting to Meghan and I congratulated her on the baby. She’s beautul. But then I said ‘it’s great chatting but what I really want to do is take the Mickey out of your husband,’ and she laughed and said ‘well here he is!’. They’re a great couple - really fun.  The duke and duchess spoke to a number of other guests including retired Australian swimmer Ian Thorpe and Australian Prime Minster Scott Morrison and his we Jenner. After  minutes they were escorted out of the room to another area of the venue ahead of the Invictus Opening Ceremony The duke, along with the Royal Foundation and Ministry of Defence, founded the games in , inspired by his visit to the US Warrior Games in . The first event was held in London, followed by Orlando in , Toronto in  and Sydney this year. No games were held in  to allow Orlando planners time to raise funds. Next years event is due to be held in Rotterdam and The Hague.

British video producer Ian Wilson and brother Jack touched down in the capital Phnom Penh on Tuesday after claiming to have found the plane on Google Maps . The MH flight had been en route from Kuala Lumpar to Beijing when it vanished on March ,  with  passengers and  crew members on boad. Ian and Jack started their trek to the site yesterday but have been warned to stay away as the site is reportedly surrounded by armed illegal loggers high on crystal meth. Theyve been warned the area of mountainous terrain between Chrok La Eang Waterfalls is re with danger.  According to the Daily Star , an unnamed expat emailed Wilson to say: The real danger you have is not so much the terrain, but the illegal loggers who are operating in the area and would not be pleased to see white guys wandering around with recording equipment. I dont want you to get into a potentially dangerous situation, either in the jungle or with these guys . The aircraft in the Google Maps image is believed to be one that was captured in flight but Wilson is convinced its the doomed MH plane.  The finders fee for the plane currently stands at poundmillion. The official search for the main wreckage of the plane, with some scraps found, was recently called off. The plane turned off course and disappeared from the radar never to be seen again and investigators presume it crashed in the Indian Ocean, west of Australia. But some theorists claim Captain Ahmad deliberately crashed the plane - a theory that has never been substatinated.  Investigators have suggested the possibility of hijacking but there is no psychological or criminal evidence to suggest any of the crew deliberately crashed the plane. Three pieces of wreckage believed to be from MH have been found from as far north as Tanzania and as far south as South Africa. Investigators have considered more than  theories about what could have happened to the plane and have worked extensively since the plane vanished. However, despite releasing a ,-page report , they admitted they still cannot say what happened.

story: NewsParents and doctors stunned after -week-old baby grows fang tooth overnightParents Tara and Brian OByrne, from Ireland, were left reeling when they discovered the spiked tooth in baby Oscars mouthShareCommentsByAilbhe DalyElaine McCahill:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe parents of an -week-old baby were shocked when he grew a fang tooth overnight "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe parents of an -week-old baby boy were left shocked when he grew a fang tooth overnight. Speaking to the Irish Daily Mirror , mum Tara said: I went in to him around am. I usually give him a soother and he goes back asleep for an hour, but he kept crying. “So I took him out and changed him but when I went to feed him, I found the tooth in his mouth. title: un climate change expert facing
story: NewsUN climate change expert facing sex offence trial accused of wrongful restraint and sending unwanted messagesLawyers for -year-old Rajendra K. Pachauri said he denies the charges, made as the MeToo movement sweeps IndiaShareByCharlotte Neal:,  OCT NewsPachauri resigned from his UN post after being slapped with sexual harassment claims "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of the worlds leading climate change experts is facing trial over alleged sex offences as Indias MeToo movement rocks the country. Rajendra K. Pachauri, who previously chaired the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, denies making physical advances, wrongful restraint, sending unwanted emails, and messages. The -year-old had stepped down from the  in  following a sexual harassment complaint by a researcher at Pachauris Delhi-based The Energy and Resources Institute . An Indian court has ordered the trial, which Mr Pachauri has asked to be speedy due to his age, his counsel Ashish Dikshit told Reuters today.  India is also considering tightening sexual harassment laws, officials told Reuters last week. The Delhi court has charged Mr Pachauri under sections of the Indian Penal code including sexual harassment and outraging the modesty of a woman. The trial begins on January , his counsel said.  The complainant will be present to record her statement and be cross-examined by the scientists lawyers, Indian news channel NDTV reports. She was reportedly a researcher who had worked directly under Pachauri in .After filing a complaint against the scientist, he was granted anticipatory bail in the case on March  of that same year. Another woman accused Pachauri of making sexual advances on her more than ten years ago and condemned the TERI for appointing him to the prestigious position. The claims were followed up by a ,-long charge sheet by the Delhi Police at the beginning of March  stating there was sufficient evidence to prove Pachauri had sexually harassed, stalked and threatened the complainant, NDTV reports.  Further Whatsapp chats and text messages between the defendant and the complainant were deemed not fabricated in the final report. The claims come as the MeToo movement sweeps India, with a large number of women accusing public figures in the media and entertainment industry of sexual misconduct. Junior government minister Mobashar Jawed Akbar resigned from his post last week after being slapped with allegations of sexual harassment by more than  women during his careers as a journalist. Akbar announced his decision on Tuesday as he sues his first accuser, journalist Priya Ramani, of defamation.
