We want to continue to meet demand for high-quality facilities and look at what improvements might be necessary.ldquoThatrsquos why we have secured funding contributions from developers who are building or will be building homes in the area, and are working with enjoyleisure to identy options for future investment. We look forward to engaging with users of the centre and the community in due course.

title: call-for-more-bungalows-to-be-built-in-east-lothian
story: Councillor Willie Innes, council leader, has urged planning officials to include a provision in negotiations with future developers for homes which can accommodate disabled and elderly people.He said: ldquoThere has to be a recognition that these kind of houses are in short supply and across East Lothian we need more single-storey houses for elderly and disabled people.ldquoPeople should have the opportunity to remain in East Lothian when they need to downsize.The council leader was speaking as a planning application for  new homes south of Brodie Road, Dunbar, was approved last week.Community councillor Jacquie Bell told a meeting of the planning committee that Dunbar Community Council supported the development but was disappointed by the lack of bungalows.She said: ldquoWe would have liked to have seen single-storey properties in the form of bungalows which have not been provided in Dunbar for many years.Mr Innes said he supported the call, adding: ldquoWe should ask planners when negotiating with developers that this type of housing is provided.He was backed by Councillor Brian Small, who added: ldquoIt is something planners need to think about. There is a market for it there are people looking to downsize and it is down to us as a council to address this issue.

title: it-was-like-being-in-a-washing-machine-says-forth-swim-fundraiser
story: A total of  swimmers took to the start line at South Queensferry to brave the chilly waters as they attempted to swim . miles to North Queensferry.However, unexpectedly strong winds meant a number of swimmers had to be saved by Coastguard and RNLI crews.Jane Calder, who was raising funds for Duo Gymnastics, was among those reaching dry land after a -minute swim.She said: ldquoI managed it I got across, which was the main thing. It was very tough.ldquoThe weather conditions turned and I got pulled by a large current under the railway bridge but eventually I got to the other side.The gymnastics club, which is based at Haddingtonrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre, plans to buy a new vaulting table, which will cost about pound,.Janersquos son Cameron is a member of the gymnastics club, which has adapted lessons for him.Jane previously told the Courier: ldquoIt has made him not feel dferent and he still feels part of the club ndash he really enjoys it.ldquoCameronrsquos disability comes under Global Development Delay. He has a real dficulty with comprehension and understanding what is being asked of him, following instructions. He is also very sensitive to noise and sudden loud noises.ldquoThat is what they have managed to do really well, break it down into small parts for him.ldquoThrough time it becomes a routine and he understands what is being asked of him.Jane, who previously represented Scotland at the  Commonwealth Games in synchronised swimming, smashed her fundraising target, collecting pound,..She said: ldquoI set out to raise pound, for the new vaulting table and I have been overwhelmed by peoplersquos generosity. The total I have raised is almost pound,.ldquoThis means that not only can the club purchase the new vaulting table, they can also purchase a new spring board and an apparatus transport trolley.ldquoMany local children are going to benefit from the new equipment.ldquoEversquos Foundation has very kindly offered to part match the amount I raised and this additional money will be used to purchase a new set of bars for the gymnasts.ldquoI would like to thank everyone involved for their kind donations, support and encouragement which made this challenge all the more lsquoenjoyablersquo!On the swim, Jane, who lives near Gford, said: ldquoYou could see people congregating at the other side.ldquoAt that point I got swept by the current, which took me right under the Forth Bridge.ldquoIt was a bit like being in a washing machine.ldquoIt was so choppy and I was trying to get out the danger zone and swimming my heart out. Eventually, I managed to get into a calmer bit and over the finish line.The mum-of-two signed up for the swim in March and linked up with the Bass Rock Swimmers, who enjoy outdoor swimming near North Berwick.Jane intends to keep on swimming outdoors and told the Courier: ldquoEvery time I cross the bridge now, I can say: lsquoIrsquove swam across there.rsquoTo support Jane, go to justgiving crowdfunding jane-calder

title: councils-ambition-for-fleet-of-fully-electric-bin-lorries
story: It is investigating making its waste collections more environmentally friendly.The move is being championed by its new head of infrastructure, who has spent the last  years revolutionising the way the county deals with waste.Tom Reid has taken over the role after running the councilrsquos waste services for two decades.And he hopes to bring his experience to the fore as he spearheads a move towards electric vehicles and more cycle paths and walkways as the council puts forward its active travel strategy.East Lothian Council recycles  per cent of its waste and produces a quality of waste which makes it appealing to companies to buy. The use of recycling boxes rather than bins and the introduction of food waste caddies has helped the county produce high-quality waste with fewer contaminants, meaning less has to be sent for treatment.Now Mr Reid wants to bring a similar approach to travel in the county as East Lothian prepares for an influx of new residents due to a plethora of new housing developments.And he revealed talks were under way to try and replace the councilrsquos refuse collection vehicles with electric versions as it looks to lead by example.He said: ldquoThe public bought into recycling because we gave them options such as the food waste bins and also because they knew it was the right thing to do.ldquoActive travel will be an evolution but we need to give people access to it. We need to provide cycle paths and safe walkways we need train services to be on time. If we can develop plans to provide these services then people will automatically select not to take the car, just as they will select electric vehicles as they become cheaper too.ldquoIt is about getting the message out and empowering people to be able to do it.The introduction of electric bin lorries would be a huge step towards improving the environment and changing public perception.Some such lorries are being trialled in England by waste recycling firms, with one company in Sheffield introducing two vehicles which are powered by burning non-recyclable rubbish as they collect it. Others are being tested using rechargeable lithium-ion batteries.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe are actively working with partners to deliver one of the first fully electric refuse collection vehicles that would be powered through renewable energy currently generated on site at Kinwegar [recycling centre near Wallyford].

title: update-dog-that-bit-off-mans-genitals-put-down
story: The -year-old man was taken to hospital in Edinburgh following the attack on Sunday, October .The Courier understands that the man, who remains in a serious condition, had his genitals bitten off by a bulldog at a flat in thecentre of Haddington.: Man seriously injured in horror dog attackThe dog was subsequently seized by police.Today , a spokeswoman for Police Scotland said: "Inquiries are continuing to establish the full circumstances of how a -year-old man sustained signicant injury to his groin area while within an address in Haddington on Sunday, October ."However, as part of this investigation,the owner of the dogwhich is believed to have been involvedhas voluntarily signed documentation consenting to the destruction of the animal."Police have now released an additional statement, which adds: "This has now taken place after protracted dialogue between the Crown Office, Scottish SPCA and the East Lothian Council Dog Warden."

title: virtual-reality-firm-to-get-new-home-in-east-linton
story: A single-storey building on the site of the Auction Mart will become home to Viarama.The ldquoinnovative and unique business, launched three years ago, describes itself as the worldrsquos first virtual reality social enterprise.Now East Lothian Council has given the green light for the building, which will be created at the site off East Lintonrsquos Station Road.A planning officerrsquos report noted there had been no objections from members of the public towards the application, which was submitted by East Linton Mart.The report reads: ldquoIn its position and by virtue of its relatively low height, the proposed building would not appear as an overly prominent or incongruous feature within its setting.ldquoWhilst it would be of a relatively simple design, the proposed building with its timber clad walls would sit comfortably within the larger former East Linton Sale Ground and Auction Mart site, and it would be acceptable for its place.The business offers the chance for people to enjoy ious virtual reality scenarios ndash from driving a rally car and flying a Spitfire to standing atop Mount Everest ndash by wearing specialist virtual reality headsets.Richard Heggie, from Urban Animation, representing the applicant, said: ldquoThe proposal brings an innovative and unique service to the site, helping to regenerate the Mart and East Linton as a whole.A number of older temporary buildings and two polytunnels will be removed from the site.

title: last-ash-lagoons-at-levenhall-to-become-a-wildlife-haven
story: The lagoons at Levenhall Links were used to dispose of ash produced by the coal-fired power station during its letime.The power station closed in  and work has been carried out to convert the ash lagoons into areas for people to enjoy as per the Musselburgh Agreement drawn up between the local authority of the time and South of Scotland Electricity Board in .The area was taken over by ScottishPower following privatisation in .A large part of the -hectare ash lagoons has already been restored and handed over to East Lothian Council and has become a rich habitat for wildle.This month the local authorityrsquos planning committee gave the go-ahead for work to continue on the two remaining lagoons before they are also handed over.The entire site is a Scottish Wildle Trust listed wildle site, is part of the Firth of Forth Site of Special Scientic Interest and considered an important roosting site for wading birds.The area attracts bird watchers from all over the country and played host to the RSPB Big Nature Festival in  and .Councillor Willie Innes, council leader, welcomed the final part of the restoration, which will see wetlands and roosting areas created, along with footpaths and bird hides on the site.He said: ldquoThe restoration of the lagoons has been a success story, built over a number of years.ldquoIt is a valuable open space in Musselburgh and it will be great to get it completed.ldquoThere is a huge ersity in wildle which the public can access right on their doorstep.

title: scotlands-youngest-lifeboat-volunteer-joins-his-dad-on-dunbar-crew
story: Kieran Fairbairn is still at Dunbar Grammar School but has been given permission to respond to emergencies ndash evenit means racing from the classroom.The teenager, who turned  in August, has begun his RNLI training and will serve on both of Dunbarrsquos two leboats ndash the all-weatherand the D-class inshore .Anyone looking to join the RNLI must be at least , with Kieran receiving his pager a month after his birthday.And he has some big boots to fill, with his dad Gary and great-great-great grandfather awarded medals for bravery after daring rescues at sea.Kieran, who will link up with his dad, the leboatrsquos coxswain, said: ldquoLeboats have been in my family since forever. Irsquove grown up around it, Irsquove been a herald for Dunbarrsquos Leboat Day celebrations and I used to watch my dad going off on rescues from our window.ldquoNow it feels fantastic to have the pager and be part of the crew myself.Kieran is in his final year at secondary school, studying National  maths and biology and Higher modern studies, but he might have to put his work on hold should the pager go off in class.He said: ldquoMy teachers have given me special dispensation to be out of class.ldquoI might have to wait a while before I get my first shout but I hope, with the training I have to do, when the time comes Irsquoll be ready.Although leboats have been in the Fairbairn familyrsquos blood, Gary, , says it wasnrsquot a given that his son would follow in his footsteps.The full-time coxswain and volunteer for  years said: ldquoIt came as a shock to me, to be honest, when he asked to join. I had asked himhe was interested in the past but he never showed much enthusiasm. I wasnrsquot going to push him. It always had to be up to him.ldquoAnd we are very grateful to have the understanding and co-operation of his teachers at Dunbar Grammar School.The Fairbairn name is so synonymous with saving lives at sea in Dunbar the town named a street ndash Fairbairn Way ndash in their honour.Gary, whose daughter Jodi, , is also ldquodesperate to join the RNLI, was awarded the bronze medal ndash and his crew medal certicates ndash for bravery after the rescue in May  of a couple from their stricken yacht in force nine winds and -metre waves.More than a century before, in , Walter Fairbairn was awarded the silver medal for helping save the lives of  men in a seagoing yacht that had run adrt.Garyrsquos dad David also served on the crew in the s.But Gary said there would be no favouritism towards his son, adding: ldquoNothing will change. Whatever the shout and whatever the emergency I have to pick the best crew available for the job in hand.ldquoBut at Dunbar, every volunteer gets their chance to be involved on our shouts.Although Gary is proud to see Kieran maintaining the connection, he said there were times the job really brought home to him the importance of family.He said: ldquoSome jobs have been so rough Irsquove kept the details from my family and one job sticks in my memory because we were tasked to a boy whorsquod fallen from clfs who was the same age as Kieran.ldquoI immediately thought: lsquoThat could have been him.rsquoldquoWill it be at the back of my mind, that Irsquom potentially taking my son into a dangerous situation  Of course.ldquoIn the old days multiple family members were not permitted on shouts in case of loss, but today the boats are a lot safer and sometimes it can pay to have someone you know well alongside you.ldquoMy brother-in-law Kenny Peters was my mechanic here on many rescues ndash including the yacht episode.

title: sturgeon-withdraws-from-conference-featuring-steve-bannon
story: Nicola Sturgeon had been scheduled to attend News Xchange  in Edinburgh next month, but said she ldquowould not be part of any process that risks legitimising or normalising far right, racist views.Mr Bannon, who worked on Donald Trumprsquos successful presidential election bid, haschampioned right-wing political causes since leaving the White House.I believe passionately in free speech but as @ScotGovFM I have to make balanced judgments ndash and I will not be part of any process that risks legitimising or normalising far right, racist views. I regret that the BBC has put me and others in this position. https:t.co xrHZkaRmdash Nicola SturgeonOctober , Ms Sturgeon tweeted: ldquoI believe passionately in free speech but as Scotlandrsquos First Minister I have to make balanced judgements ndash and I will not be part of any process that risks legitimising or normalising far right, racist views.News Xchange is a gathering of journalists and media operators from around the world. Mr Bannon is scheduled to be interviewed by the BBCrsquos Sarah Smith.BBC News and BBC Scotland are listed as host partners of the event atEdinburgh International Conference Centre November  and , and Ms Sturgeon said ldquoI regret that the BBC has put me and others in this position.It is understood the First Minister was due to speak at the opening reception at the National Museum of Scotland on November .Who are you looking forward to hearing speak at the #NX Heres a list of some of our speakers mdashgthttps:t.co ZdoKyMI pic buIaqreimdash News XchangeOctober , She tweeted: ldquoThe email the BBC sent to my office justying Bannonrsquos inclusion described him as a lsquopowerful and influential figure hellip promoting an anti-elite movement.rsquo This kind of language to describe views that many would describe as fascist does seem to me to run the risk of normalisation.A spokesperson for the event organisers told journalists at The Ferret: ldquoNews Xchange is a journalism conference which seeks to explore the main industry trends and challenges delegates to understand the wider political and social context.ldquoSteve Bannon is a key influencer in the rise of populism ndash one of the dominant political trends of our times. He has been invited to speak at News Xchange this year because his views are relevant to todayrsquos society at large and therefore to the media industry.ldquoWe also consider it our journalistic responsibility to share and scrutinise a range of relevant viewpoints within the framework of a balanced debate.A BBC spokeswoman said: ldquoSteve Bannon was invited on behalf of the EBUrsquos News Xchange committee.ldquoGood journalism in a world of fake news and disinformation is more vital than ever. Journalism is about asking tough questions and understanding what is happening in the world and why.ldquoA conference designed to analyse the big issues impacting that world isnrsquot an endorsement of anyone or anything ndash it is aof what journalism is.Its those who give media s to dangerous far right extremists like Bannon who *make* them powerful and influential. The BBC must withdraw the invitation. https:t.co JJRcnGNYJmdash Patrick Harvie ##October , Green MSP Patrick Harvie commented: ldquoSteve Bannon has been centrally involved in the attempt to re-boot the far right, both in the US and in Europe.ldquoTo normalise such dangerous extremists and give them media s of this kind only serves to give them a veneer of legitimacy.ldquoWhen the rise of fascism threatens so many people across the world, there must be a clear line drawn between democratic politics and extremism and the BBC must recognise that line.

title: europe-is-a-force-for-peace-in-n-ireland-and-around-the-world-rally-told
story: A sizeable crowd waving EU flags and carrying anti-DUP placards converged outside Belfast city hall on Saturday afternoon.Even some of the dogs on the street bore the blocrsquos blue and gold symbol.Cross-community Alliance Party leader Naomi Long said: ldquoWe have the EU to thank for the longest period of peace and stability on the continentof Europe in history.ldquoThe EU forced nations to compromise, forced people to come together on the big issues like climate change.ldquoIt underpinned the peace. The EU spent money underpinning the peace right across Europe, from the fall of the Berlin Wall, which could have been chaotic, right through to the former Yugoslavia.ldquoNowhere did it do that more so than right here.She said the Brexit debate was not about protecting the UKrsquos union or creating a united Ireland, as it has been characterised by some on opposite sides of the issue.Just in case anyone was wondering what NI thinks of Brexithellip #RallyRemain pic LDTbMVGGmdash James GordonOctober , Mrs Long said: ldquoThis is about the people of this place coming together and saying, just like the EU, we value cooperation, we value immigration, we value working together in the best interests of everyone in this society.ldquoThat is why we value the EU, it is not just a model of cooperation, it underpins the very cooperation that we need here.Northern Ireland voted to remain in the EU by %.One placard hoisted aloft in the crowd said: ldquo% say protect Good Friday.People fanned out around a stage in front of the city hall down the main shopping street, Donegall Place, to hear speeches focused on environmental, human rights, business and student concerns.Residents of border communities who oppose Brexit were also present.The crowd held a range of placards, including one proclaiming: ldquoWe wonrsquot be DUPrsquoed in reference to the pro-Brexit Northern Irish partyrsquos partnership with Theresa Mayrsquos Conservatives at Westminster.Donald Trump and Vladimir Putinrsquos apparent support for Brexit was referenced as a reason for Northern Ireland to reject it.Other slogans demanded a Peoplersquos Vote, a second referendum, which another podium speaker, SDLP South Belfast Assembly member Claire Hanna, said Brexiteers should have nothing to fear fromthey are so wedded to democracy.She added: ldquoNobody voted to be poorer.Fab turnout at Rally for REMAIN at Belfast City Hall pic dzYViVmdash Damian McGenityOctober , John Barry, a Queenrsquos University professor associated with the Green Party in Northern Ireland, also attacked the Brexiteers.He said: ldquoThey are drunk on magical thinking around making England great again and continuing the border with science fiction technology and an exaggerated sense of their importance in the world and they show no signs of sobering up.Meanwhile, Sinn Fein vice-president Michelle OrsquoNeill said Brexiteers had exhibited ldquoreckless disregard for the people of Northern Ireland.ldquoThey care nothing for jobs or for rights and are prepared to drive our economy over the clf.

title: scottish-green-party-members-back-peoples-vote
story: Members at the partyrsquos autumn conference in Glasgow voted in favour of a motion supported by co-conveners Patrick Harvie and Maggie Chapman.The policy of a Peoplersquos Vote is already held by the Green Party in England and Wales.Conference overwhelmingly backed that the people should have a say in the final #Brexit deal before leaving the European Union by way of a referendum #mdash Scottish GreensOctober , Mr Harvie said: ldquoThe events of the next few weeks and months will pose a critical threat not only to the immediate prospects for our country and for our neighbours, but also to the future of our democracy and Scotlandrsquos Parliament.ldquoScottish Green Party members have said unequivocally that voters in the UK must have the final say on any Brexit deal or no deal.ldquoWe can now look forward to campaigning with our Green colleagues throughout the rest of the UK for a Peoplersquos Vote.The MSP described the Brexit process as ldquoincompetent chaos and a ldquodirect assault on the authority of our Parliament.He said the Scottish Greens remain committed to Scotlandrsquos future as an independent country which is a full member of Europe.He added: ldquoThe extreme Brexiteers are already flirting with the sociopaths of the US libertarian right, the same outfits which have been a force for ill from climate denial to union-busting.ldquoThatrsquos the agenda these people want to impose on us ndash one in which the social, environmental and workplace rights and protections which were fought for by generations before us are torn to pieces in the pursuit of an already failed economic system.Great to be with so many @scotgp members at #sgpconf in Glasgow ndash people who know the climate crisis demands the urgent transformation that other parties have never grasped. #Divest Now!mdash Patrick Harvie ##October , The conference also heard from Green member of the Irish senate, Grace OrsquoSullivan, who warned of concern in Ireland that the UK is ldquothree seconds from midnight in the Brexit negotiations but appears to have no resolutions to key problems.She said: ldquoBrexit is something that we discuss every day in Dublin, every day in Ireland, in fact itrsquos on everyonersquos mind.ldquoA guillotine blade hanging ominously over the political, economic and social progress that has defined the island of Ireland since the Good Friday Agreement came into effect.She said there is cross-party agreement in Ireland to look to the EU and the UK to ldquoprotect the peaceful and borderless island we have worked so hard to create.

title: do-not-approach-it-black-panther-on-the-loose-in-ayrshire
story: The big cat was reported in fields near the B, close to the villages of Drongan and Coalhall, prompting a police safety warning.The SSPCA hadbeen called in to help catch the black panther, which may be injured. However, the charity has since confirmed it will not be joining in with the hunt.POLICE SAFETY WARNING - DRONGAN AND COALHALLOfficers are asking residents to be vigilant after a report has been received of a sighting of what is believed to be a black panther in the fields near to the B. Do not approach it, contact Police via .https:t.co rmsCds pic psFmPUHWDDDog walkers have been warned to be on alert.A spokesman for Police Scotland said: ldquoResidents in Drongan and Coalhall are being advised by officers to be vigilant after a report has been received of a sighting of what is believed to be a black panther in the fields near to the B between the two villages.ldquoOfficers are currently working with the SSPCA to locate the animal which may be injured.ldquoThe area is popular with dog walkers so care should be taken andanyone sees the animal we would ask you not to approach it.The Scottish SPCA said it would not be joining in the search for the animal - because its team is ldquounequipped.Animal rescue officer, Alistair Hill, said: ldquoWe can confirm we have received reports regarding a possible panther sighting in Ayr.ldquoWe have liaised with Police Scotland and informed them we are unequipped to deal with such animals and, therefore, will not be involved in investigating the incident.

title: brewdog-opens-first-cryptocurrency-bar-in-canary-wharf
story: It is the Aberdeenshire-based firms tenth bar in London, th in the UK and th worldwide, with more in the pipeline that potentially includes one in Kirkwall in Orkney.New locations for BrewDog franchise bars also include Ayr, Oban, Edinburgh Airport and North Berwick.The new London bar will be Brewdogs first to accept Bitcoin and Bitcoin Cash and joins Clerkenwell in becoming a cashless bar.The firm said it plans to expand cashless and cryptocurrency payments across its fleet of global bars in the near future.Referencing Canary Wharfrsquos position as a financial hub, the brewer is launching a draft beer for which the price correlates with the movement of the FTSE .An electronic dot matrix affixed above the bar will relay the latest dayrsquos trading results, and the correlating price fluctuation of the "Hop Exchange" beer.James Watt, co-founder of BrewDog, above, said: "Our Canary Wharf bar further strengthens Londonrsquos claim to be the new craft beer capital of the world."The demand for better beer keeps growing every month and it reaches every community in the city."He also said: "Wersquove always prided ourselves on our desire to keep innovating."Wersquove done it with beer, wersquove done it with our business model, and now we are championing a new way of paying for a pint."Mr Watt claimed: "Our Canary Wharf bar is the bellwether of a payment revolution."In its fth round of crowdfunding, which closed this week, the Ellon firm raised more than poundm.The company said it had been "blown away by support from over , awesome craft beer crusaders" who have helped raise more than poundm in total.The brewery announced its first-half trading update in August showing total revenue at poundm, up by % on the same period of the previous year.An event aimed at people interested in taking franchises is being held at its HQ next month.

title: grave-of-forgotten-scots-hero-who-helped-abolish-slavery-finally-marked
story: But outside the dusty tomes of academia, the extraordinary story of Zachary Macaulay has largely been forgotten.Now the final resting place of the pioneering activist ndash whose horric experiences in the Jamaican plantations and forensic attention to detail helped change the world forever ndash is to be marked for the first time with a memorial plaque.Born in Inveraray in , Macaulay overcame a misspent youth binge-drinking on the streets of Glasgow to become the governor of Sierra Leone, and later helped lay the foundations for the abolition of slavery in .His biographer Rev Dr Iain Whyte insists Macaulay provided the crucial ldquoammunition that allowed key figures such as William Wilberforce to force a change in the law.He said: ldquoHe collected the material and Wilberforce used it. I would have to say strongly that it would have taken longer to abolish slavery but for the campaigning of people like Zachary.Professor John Cairns of Edinburgh University argues Macaulays direct experience gave him ldquoan extra moral authority.Despite this, his vital role is often overlooked.A son of the manse, Macaulay left school at  and travelled to Glasgow to work in a merchantrsquos office ndash where he quickly fell in with a rowdy crowd and developed a taste for booze.Things took a turn for the worse when a mysterious, shameful event led him to pack his bags and head for Jamaica. Macaulay never ulged what happened, but some have speculated the teenager got a girl pregnant.In Jamaica, he worked as a ldquobookkeeper ndash or slave overseer ndash at a sugar plantation. Just  years old, he was at first horried by the brutality around him, but he hardened over time.It was only after he ed to Britain in  that he came into contact with anti-slavery campaigners and developed a fervent belief that the law must be changed. His guilt over his time in Jamaica would come to haunt him.Through working with the evangelical Clapham Sect ndash a group of abolitionists with the politician William Wilberforce at their centre ndash Macaulay was invited to visit Sierra Leone, the African colony established to provide a home for emancipated slaves. He became its governor while still in his mid-s.In , he ed to England on a slave ship to experience the conditions first-hand, and dedicated himself to abolition.The slave trade was outlawed across the British Empire in . But Macaulays work wasnt finished, and he went on to launch the monthly Anti-Slavery Reporter.His attention to detail and statistical know-how armed Wilberforce and the abolitionists with the facts they needed to argue the case for further reform in Westminster.Slavery itself was abolished in , and Macaulay died five years later. He was buried in a cemetery in London, but after the site became a public park ndash St Georgersquos Gardens ndash the exact location of his grave was lost.Now, to mark the th anniversary of his birth, a memorial plaque will be unveiled in the gardens after being donated by the Royal Statistical Society , the Friends of St Georgersquos Gardens, University College London and the Clan Macaulay Association.Sir David Spiegelhalter, president of the RSS, described him as an ldquounsung hero. He added: ldquoThe people who quietly gather the evidence dont always get noticed, which is why we think its so great that Macaulays contribution is being remembered today."

title: brexit-cant-be-soft-says-michel-barnier-insisting-there-is-no-added-value-in-britain-leaving-eu
story: The EUrsquos chief Brexit negotiator, following this weekrsquos inconclusive Brussels summit, warned that while  per cent of the deal was done, it could still fail over the Irish border issue.Speaking to France-Inter radio, he said: "A deal is possible, it is desirable but it is dficult," noting how his hope was to complete it "in a few weeks or a few months as soon as possible".Mr Barnier admitted he had ldquono deep conviction that an agreement could be reached, noting how the political situation in the UK was ldquovery complex and I dont know what decisions Theresa May will take.He explained one "extremely serious" outstanding issue was the need to ensure there was no hard border in Ireland. Askedthe whole deal could fall over this one point, he replied bluntly: "My answer is yes."While the chief negotiator acknowledged a failure to get a Brexit deal would be ldquovery serious, very dficult for all of us in the EU, it would be ldquomuch more grave for Britain".Challenged over whether no-deal would mean dramatic disruption, such as flights being grounded, he said: "Emergency solutions would be found to establish a certain continuity but it would be extremely serious."Mr Barnier then stressed the negative essence of Britainrsquos decision to leave the European bloc."There is no added value in Brexit. It is a negative negotiation. No-one has been able to show me any added value in Brexit, not even Mr Farage.ldquoWhen I met him in my office at his request and I asked him: Show me how the decision to leave the EU provides solutions to the anxieties, discontents and sometimes the anger of the British people."He made clear he did not want to impose a hard Brexit on Britain, which he described as the ldquoabsence of a deal."But Brexit cant be soft. It has innumerable consequences. It was chosen by the British. Were they well informed at the time they voted  They were not told all the consequences even Mr Farage recognised that everything was not spelt out in the campaign."Mr Barnier said he believed that the Brexit vote was driven in part by "nostalgia" as well as the UKs desire to extricate itself from regulations, particularly in the financial sector, and popular anger over the impact of economic liberalisation.But David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary hit back, saying: "I wouldnt confuse belief in the free market with nostalgia.Earlier, Jeremy Hunt rejected claims that Theresa May had "capitulated" in the face of EU demands.The Foreign Secretary insisted: "The reason why this week has been dficult is because Theresa May has not buckled. She has held firm. She has stuck to her principles. It is precisely because she has not capitulated that we have not concluded this agreement.After attending the EU-Asia summit in Brussels, the Prime Minister briefed around  business leaders on the Brexit negotiations, hosting a video roundtable with chief executives and chairmen and women from firms including Tesco, RBS and Diageo, plus business groups like the CBI and Federation of Small Businesses.Meanwhile, Sammy Wilson, the Democratic Unionistsrsquo Brexit spokesman, took Leo Varadkar, the Irish premier, to task after he warned that violence could againto the island of Irelanda hard border was imposed post-Brexit.Branding the Taoiseach ldquovile, Mr Wilson accused him of "despicable, low and rotten" behaviour, claiming Mr Varadkar was scraping the bottom of a "very deep barrel of threats, deception and rhetoric".But Simon Coveney, Irelandrsquos Deputy Prime Minister, defended his colleague, saying: "We are not trying to scaremonger here, what we are trying to do here is protect a very precious peace and normality on the island of Ireland."

title: vince-cable-brexit-is-a-betrayal-of-the-younger-generation-by-the-older-generation
story: Politicians from across all the main parties will speak at the event, which will be addressed by Nicola Sturgeon via a video link.Her SNP colleague MP Joanna Cherry will speak on the stage alongside Sadiq Khan, the London Mayor, his Labour colleague Chuka Umunna, Conservative Anna Soubry and the Greensrsquo Caroline Lucas.Sir Vince, the Liberal Democrat leader, will also speak and is due to say: "Tragically, Brexit ides one generation from another. A substantial majority of my generation voted to leave. A substantial majority of the young voted to remain. Your generation is being betrayed by mine. By those who look to the past, who see Britain as a museum."Fellow Peoplersquos Vote campaigner Labours Lord Adonis, said: "Brexits becoming a dogs dinner."This weeks fresh chaos and confusion over Brexit negotiations has exposed how even the best deal now available will be a bad one for Britain."Its a mess that nobody voted for and the reason were in such a growing crisis is that those cheerleading for Brexit know the promises they made can never be kept.The former minister said the campaign was about using people power to address the wrongs of a botched Brexit process."This is about making sure MPs understand how strong feelings are running on this vital issue. If they are wavering, they need to know there is a political price to be paid for doing the wrong thing."Voters will neither forgive nor forgetMPs allow this miserable Brexit to proceed without people being given the final say," added the peer.Among the celebrities attending the event will be celebrity cook Delia Smith, Dragons Den businesswoman Deborah Meaden. The rally is being compered by broadcasters Richard Bacon and Mariella Frostrup.Video messages will be played from comedians Mitch Benn and Patrick Kielty as well as former footballer Gary Lineker.As part of the campaign, called #WriteThisWrong, , postcards will be distributed which have been imprinted with the words: ldquoBrexit has already become a dogrsquos dinner. The whole process is going badly wrong. And itrsquos only going to get worse.Some  coachloads of people from across the country are expected to head to the march, with around  vehicles sponsored by famous names including football manager Alan Pardew, actor Natascha McElhone, writer Armando Iannucci, former footballer Jamie Carragher and singer Olly Alexander.The march will begin at midday in Park Lane before the rally take place in Parliament Square.

title: scottish-tory-mps-could-vote-down-budget-as-tempers-flare-over-extending-brexit-transition-period
story: According to one backbencher, David Mundell, the Scottish Secretary, would ldquoprobably resignTheresa May pursued this course.The Herald has been told several of the  Scottish Tories have told the party whips they are intent on making a firm stand on the issue and would be compelled to vote against the Governmentit opposed their wishes.Askedthis could include voting down Philip Hammondrsquos Budget, one Scottish Tory MP said: ldquoAnything is possible.The  Democratic Unionists, who prop up the Conservative Government, have already threatened to vote against the Budget ndash which in theory could topple the May administration ndash over the prospect of Northern Ireland remaining in the single market with a border down the Irish Sea.While the Prime Minister has stressed she is not proposing any extension to the -month transition period, equally she has not ruled one out.It has been claimed a few days ago her War Cabinet of  senior ministers privately talked through the prospect of a transition period extension without the knowledge of the full Cabinet. Mr Mundell is not a member of Mrs Mayrsquos inner team.At the EU summit on Thursday, Jean-Claude Juncker, the European Commission President, said a transition period extension would afford both sides more time to agree a trade deal and so avoid a backstop he added it "probably will happen".When the Scottish Secretary got wind of this possibility, he telephoned Downing Street and spoke to a top official, making clear his deep concern.A source close to Mr Mundell insisted there was no threat of resignation and suggestions to this effect were being ldquoovercooked, noting how there was at present no clarity about an extension. ldquoIts just an idea that has not been fleshed out," he said.However, one MP said there was deep alarm among Scottish Conservatives.ldquoThis is a red line for us, he declared. ldquoIf fishing were included in the extension period ndash and Brussels would want it to be - there is absolutely no way we could support it. It would mean us voting against the Government and David Mundell would probably resign.The backbencher said the Government had to know the  Scottish Conservative MPs were ldquowilling to flex their muscleswe are pushed into a corner.He added: ldquoFishing is a totemic issue in Scotland and I can see myself going through the lobbies against the Governmentneed be which is not something I ever thought I would hear myself say.Another Scottish Tory MP was equally adamant that he too would vote against the Governmentfishing were not exempted from a transition extension. ldquoYes, I would. I have already told the whips. All  of us feel the same way. I donrsquot know of any colleague who would not hold the line on this.A third MP pointed out how the Government had initially given its word that the UK would take back control of its fishing waters from December  but then it was pushed back to December  due to the transition period any further extension to December  would cost the party seats in Scotland. ldquoPeople would rightly feel betrayed by such a move, he declared.Simon Collins of the Shetland Fishermenrsquos Association made a similar point, saying the industry should ldquonot be let down again as it was under the s Heath Government and that the UK Government had given it a ldquocast-iron guarantee that Britain would become an independent coastal state on Brexit Day and leave the EUrsquos Common Fisheries Policy.ldquoIn March this year, we were told there is going to be an implementation period and yoursquore stuck shadowing the CFP until the end of . We didnrsquot like that at all. That was a whf of betrayal alreadyhellipIf you go back again and say it might not be until December , why should people believe anything the Government saysthey carry on like that Earlier, Jeremy Hunt accepted the issue of the transition extension was ldquovery dficult but suggested it might be helpful to seal a trade deal.The Foreign Secretary called on Tory colleagues to unite behind the PM as the EU were united behind Michel Barnier, their chief Brexit negotiator, to ldquomaximise her chances of success.Meanwhile, Tory Remainer Nicky Morgan, the former Education Secretary, said the Conservatives had been put under "existential strain" by Brexit and some friendships and relationships would "never be healed".

title: british-built-spacecraft-heads-for-planet-mercury
story: BepiColombo was blasted into space from the European space port at Kourou, French Guiana, at about .am UK time on Saturday.It was carried on top of an Ariane , the European Space Agencyrsquosmost powerful rocket.After a tense countdown in French the rocket rose slowly above a ball of orange flame and thundered into the sky before disappearing into cloud.Ltoff of #Ariane! #BepiColomboWatch live: https:t.co JVwQjTa pic rpauaoQpnmdash ESAOctober , Now begins a complex journey for the spacecraft that will take seven years and cross five billion milesof space.Following the ldquoescape trajectory launch, BepiColombo will swing past the Earth in a wide curve before first heading for Venus.In  it will place two probes, one European the other Japanese, in orbit around Mercury, the least explored world in the solar system.Speaking after the launch, Professor Gunther Hasinger, ESArsquos director of science, said: ldquoThis is truly breathtaking. We have today written history.ldquoWe have sent the most complex stack of spacecraft that ever have been conceived into space, and to a very long journey to an environment which is truly out of the Earth truly out of this world.The Mercury Transfer Module , carrying the orbiters, was built in Stevenage by the Defence and Space ision of aerospace company Airbus.Key elements of ESAs Mercury Planet Orbiter were also assembled by Airbus in the UK.Scientists hope the pound. billion mission will unravel some of Mercuryrsquos many mysteries, such as the reason for its oversized iron core, its spectacular volcanic vents, and tantalising hints of water ice in shadowy parts of the scorching hot planet.The answers they get will shed new light on the origins and evolution of the solar system.A key feature of BepiColombo is that it is the first interplanetary mission to employ advanced electric ion propulsion technology.Four Star Trek-style ldquoimpulse engines, two firing at a time, will emit beams of electrically charged, or ldquoionised, xenon gas.After years of planning, training and simulations, here is the moment that #BepiColombo## left Earth#on its mission to explore #Mercury#https:t.co jpXUiQRgUl pic nzStdPcmdash ESA OperationsOctober , They will be used not to accelerate the craft but to act as a brake against the sunrsquos enormous gravity.A series of fly-bys past the Earth, Venus, and Mercury will also help to reduce BepiColomborsquos velocity by km per second.At top speed after launch, the spacecraft will be moving at kmper second.One of the biggest challenges for mission planners was ensuring the spacecraft could withstand searing temperatures of more than C so close to the sun.Protective measures include a heat shield, novel ceramic and titanium insulation, ammonia-filled ldquoheat pipes, and in the case of the Japanese orbiter, ldquoroast-on-a-spit spinning.A suite of  instruments on the MPO will map the surface of Mercury and probe its chemical composition for up to two years.FIRST SIGNAL RECEIVED# from #BepiColombo##, detected by @ESAs antenna at #NewNorcia, Australia#.With these first words#, engineers at #ESOC# can monitor the status  execution of the autonomous activities onboard the spacecraft pic JkYppgAOCmdash ESA OperationsOctober , Meanwhile, the Japanese space agency Jaxarsquos Mercury Magnetospheric Orbiterrsquos five instruments will focus on the planetrsquos unusual lopsided magnetic field.One of BepiColomborsquos main instruments, the Mercury Imaging X-ray Spectrometer , was designed and built at the University of Leicester.The ion thrusters were supplied by the UK defence technology company QinetiQ.Only two spacecraft have previously visited Mercury. Nasarsquos Mariner  flew past the planet three times in - and the American space agencyrsquos Messenger probe orbited Mercury from  to .BepiColombo was named after the late Giuseppe ldquoBepi Colombo, an Italian scientist and engineer who played a leading role in the  Mariner  mission.Professor Emma Bunce, from the University of Leicester, who heads the Mixs instrument team, said after watching the launch: ldquoI didnrsquot know what to expect but it was absolutely amazing, just spectacular, the way it lit up the whole sky and the way the sound eventually reaches you. Quite emotional really.ldquoYou think about the instrument yoursquove worked for so many years on sitting on top of that rocket and you hope itrsquos going to be OK.Justin Byrne, head of science at Airbus Defence and Space, said: ldquoMy feelings are of relief. Wersquove spent  years building a complex spacecraft so itrsquos fantastic that itrsquos going on its journey. Irsquom excited about whatrsquos to come.ldquoThe engines will be switched on in a few days and that will be the crowning glory. Then we have seven years to wait for the science.ESA director general Professor Jan Woerner sounded a word of caution, pointing out that the launch was only the ldquofirst step.He added: ldquoOf course Irsquom happy that the launch worked perfectly. Now we have to see what happens in the future, but I am optimistic.Around  minutes after the launch came confirmation that BepiColombo had separated from the last stage of the Ariane  rocket.Then came the news that the  metre wide solar  had deployed successfully, which was a critical early point of the mission.

title: uk-us-cyber-accord-to-be-announced-by-defence-secretary
story: Gavin Williamson is expected to reveal the agreement during a Trafalgar Night dinner onboard HMS Queen Elizabeth, which is currently anchored two miles from Manhattan in New York.During his speech on Saturday, he will also reveal that the new Atlantic Future Forum will take place on Monday, bringing US and UK industry and military together amid the changing face of warfare, and fight against cyber threats.ldquoSome believe it is not the place for our armed forces to operate outside deployed conflict zones many thousands of miles from the UK mainland, he will say.ldquoThey are wrong. Against a threat seeking to subvert and destabilise the very fabric of our society such capabilities are critical.ldquoSo I am convinced cyber, information warfare and intelligence must be fully integrated into our military power, that they are fundamental to a modernised defence and our war fighting successes, and that without them we put our nationrsquos security at perilous risk.He will say that this is why the accord, which will be signed on Monday, will serve as a commitment from the US and UK to work with a committee of firms in cyber and articial intelligence.The aim is to ensure the special relationship remains the worldrsquos leading partnership for cyber security, defence and articial intelligence in the face of changing threats, Mr Williamson is expected to say.ldquoAggressor nations still respect our hard-won military expertise on sea, land and air. But they can now use technology to do us harm in ways once thought impossible, he will add.ldquoAlready the UK is acting ndash combining our technical excellence, our professionalism, our war fighter ethos to design and increasingly use our offensive cyber capabilities.ldquoCapability that can counter and deter malign cyber attacks and that allows us to strike swtly and strategically as Daesh have found to their cost with their evil propaganda machine wiped from the online battlespace.It comes as HMS Queen Elizabeth, Britainrsquos biggest and most powerful warship, prepares to have her systems rigorously tested against the evolving cyber danger next year as part of Information Warrior .The Royal Navy-led exercise will simulate attempts to bring down networks and jam satellite communications to ensure the fleet remains able to combat these threats, and as hostile states become more technologically advanced.

title: pro-brexit-website-accused-of-secret-sophisticated-ad-campaign-to-lobby-mps
story: The website, Mainstream Network, is accused of spending hundreds of thousands of pounds on Facebook to target voters in specic constituencies and promote pro-Brexit messages, in a report by communications firm up given to the parliamentary fake news inquiry.No information is given on the website or on social media about who owns, funds or writes for the website.Damian Collins, chairman of the fake news inquiry, said: ldquoHere we have an example ofa clearly sophisticated organisation spending lots of money on a political campaign, and we have absolutely no idea who is behind it.ldquoThe only people who know who is paying for these adverts is Facebook.Mainstream Network did not responded to requests for comment sent to its generic email address and Facebook did not respond to requests for comment before publication.Researchers at up estimate that the Mainstream Facebook page, which has , followers, has spent up to pound, to promote posts across the social network, potentially reaching almost  million people in the process.These figures would only be reachedevery share, comment or like on every post published by the Mainstream Facebook page was the result of paid advertising, however.Mike Harris, chief executive of up, said: ldquoWersquove seen very little evidence of signicant organic reach but we know they have been running a very large set of adverts on Facebook.ldquoThis has led us to believe the huge number of engagements is due to paid advertising.Mainstream also has a Twitter account with paid-for tweets but with a much smaller following.Both the website and Facebook page were also registered in late November , publishing pro-Brexit news stories and opinion pieces on a daily basis and describing itself as a ldquoNews and Media Organisation.But researchers say they found more than  Facebook adverts as recently as this week encouraging viewers to ldquotell your local MP to bin Chequers, another name for the Prime Ministerrsquos proposals for leaving the European Union.ldquoWe have reason to believe that this is part of a sophisticated advertising campaign, with pages setup [sic] to target users in every key constituency in the UK, with bespoke localised messaging encouraging users to lobby their respective MPs, they say in the report.Facebook updated its policies on political advertising in the UK on Tuesday, meaning advertisers must disclose fundingthey want to promote a political message.The Mainstream Facebook adverts targeting MPs are no longer viewable but the pages on the website remain.At least  MPs, including Mr Collins and defence secretary Gavin Williamson, are the subject of separate pages on the Mainstream website, each with a picture of the MPrsquos local constituency and a button to email them.The button opens an email on the userrsquos computer addressed to the MP and includes the same text as the webpage, demanding the MP ldquotell the Prime Minister to bin the Chequers deal and ldquodeliver full Brexit.Mainstream Network also adds its own email into the ldquoblind address field, meaning it receives a copy of the email each user sends but the MP is unaware.ldquoThatrsquos the point where the behaviour is illegal as they were copying themselves into the email to the MP to collect peoplesrsquo email addresses, alleged Mr Harris, suggesting that the addresses would be used for further marketing campaigns.Data protection laws state that any organisation collecting or storing inidualsrsquo personal data, such as email addresses, must be transparent in how and why the data is collected. No such information exists on the website.Mr Collins said: ldquoWhile debate on one of the central issues facing our country is part of a thriving democracy, there is an important question of where campaigning stops and political advertising starts.ldquoFacebook has recently announced a set of changes to increase transparency around political advertising on its .ldquoThis example offers Facebook an opportunity to show it is committed to making that change happen ndashyou are targeted with a message or asked to lobby your MP, you should know exactly who is behind the organisation asking you to do it.Rob Leathern, director of product management at Facebook, said: ldquoOn November , all advertisers will have new requirements before they can place political ads in the UK, including Mainstream Network.ldquoThese advertisers will need to confirm their identity and location through an authorisations process and accurately represent the organization or person paying for the ad in a disclaimer.ldquoThese steps must happen or the advertiser will be prevented from running ads related to politics on Facebook. We know we canrsquot prevent election interference alone and offering more ad transparency allows journalists, researchers and other interested parties to raise important questions.

title: edinburgh-workers-could-save-82000-by-commuting
story: Research by the Bank of Scotland found the dferencein house pricesbetween the capital and locations around an hour away would be enough to pay for the current annual rail costfor  years.Homes in sites including Dunblane, Glasgow, Motherwell, Dunfermline and Kirkcaldy cost pound, on average ndash pound, lower than the average price in Edinburgh city centre .A -minute commute could save homebuyers pound, with the average price for a home in places such asNorth Berwick, Dunbar, Livingston, Falkirk and Bathgate atpound,.In contrast, it is more expensive to have a longer commute to Glasgow.A -minute commute from a town such as Paisley would see homebuyers paying pound,, % less than the average house price in Glasgow city centre .An hour commute from areas including Edinburgh, Perth and Dumfries pushes house prices up to pound,, %higher than in the city centre.The study suggests Kirkcaldy is the most affordable town to live in for those travelling to Edinburgh, whereas Greenock offers the best value for money for Glasgow commuters.Graham Blair, mortgages director at Bank of Scotland, said: ldquoMany people have a desire to buy near their place of work to escape the morning commute.ldquoHowever, for some towns and cities, the premium this comes with can price out the average buyer.ldquoWith savings to be gained, it is an attractive pull for any potential purchaser to look further afield.

title: kevin-mckenna-we-dont-need-a-second-eu-vote-but-we-do-need-a-second-independence-vote
story: Others claimthat many UK citizens simply didnrsquot know what they were voting for. Well of course we didnrsquot know what we were voting for, as Britain had never previously conducted a vote on whether or not to remain in the EU. Andyou insist that those who voted to leave the EU were largely ignorant about the consequences and ramications of Brexit then the same could also be said for many who voted to Remain.How easily many Remainers choose to overlook the behaviour of the EU in bending Greece to its will, encouraged by German banks who expressed disgust at the profligacy and corruption they claimed led that country into financial distress. These same banks have since made euro. billion in interest payments on Greek bonds since . The German governmentrsquos own figures showed that Germany made euro.bn in interest payments on these bonds ndash purchased in a deal to keep the Greek economy afloat ndash while paying Greece less than eurobn. There are benefits to be had from being in the EU but, as ever, some benefit more than others.Some Remainers also become haughty when citing their reasons for holding a second referendum. In this they can barely conceal their liberal disdain for those of their fellows who unconscionably voted to leave. They portray them as a bunch of ignorant, racist and ill-educated northerners who were incapable of understanding the consequences of Brexit. Their barely-concealed glee at every presentiment of evil that may yet afflict those northern communities has been sickening.Yet, like their manufactured concerns for the future of Ireland Irsquove rarely heard any of the metropolitan elites previously profess to be overly-vexed by the challenges faced by working-class communities in Englandrsquos north-west or north-east. Where were they when the fishing fleets on Humberside disappeared, sacriced to enable the US to spy on Soviet submarines from the Icelandic coast  And beyond some hand-wringing and anti-Thatcher sloganising what did they actually do when the mines all shut and the car factories fell silent  Each time I see Gordon Brown wade into Brexit on his white charger I can still hear him say: ldquoBritish jobs for British workers. You also contributed to this, big man.Nothing wersquove seen in the British political and social landscape makes me think that a second EU referendum would bring a dferent result from the first one. The social problems encountered by Englandrsquos most disadvantaged communities are profound and figured massively in their reasons for choosing to exit the EU. These problems remain deep-rooted and those who think their reasons for voting Leave were forged solely on the big, fat NHS lie on the side of Boris Johnsonrsquos battle-buses are deluding themselves. And anyway,wersquore seriously talking about re-running the EU referendum on the claim that the idiot punters were fed myths and lies then letrsquos also have a look at every General Election held in the UK since the dawn of universal suffrage.Irsquom aware too that those of us who seek a second referendum on Scottish independence are on shaky ground here. Many of the reasons put forward for rejecting a second EU referendum might, with some justication, also apply to the prospect of a second Scottish one. And, having previously stated some obvious flaws in the arguments of recalcitrant Remainers Irsquoll refrain from pointing out the response which immediately comes to mind when Nicola Sturgeon talks about the craziness of leaving the worldrsquos most successful and robust trading confederation. Yet, there are some obvious dferences too which arguably justy a second independence referendum and a mandate too.Since September,  there have been three General Elections on either side of the Border: one for Holyrood and two for Westminster. In addition there has been a local government election. In Scotland the SNP, the only party campaigning for a second referendum, has triumphed in each of these elections comfortably. Four years on from the first referendum on Scottish independence there remains a pro-Yes majority at Holyrood. These alone constitute a mandate in anyonersquos language.Equally, there can be little doubt that the social and political terrain of the UK, as it affects Scottish citizens, has changed materially and that these changes have been profound and dramatic. As such, these take us well beyond any questions about not respecting the democratic vote of the first independence referendum. Wersquore not talking about seeking a second vote for fear of what might happen as a result of the first one but because of what actually has happened. The vote to leave the EU could stand alone here in justying a second independence referendum simply because two-thirds of Scots voted to remain.The most profound reason, though, has been evident for some time and will become critically so following Brexit, no matter what sort of deal is reached with the EU. While England has been in convulsions for a decade over the amount of migrants coming through its borders Scottish governments since  have been united behind one policy: we want them the more the merrier and we need to find ways of attracting them and persuading them to stay. They donrsquot need to earn poundk-a-year for the privilege and they wonrsquot need to know through which eye Harold had his brain skewered in . We need them because our population is ageing and there arenrsquot enough Scots paying enough to fund their care. When free movement of EU citizens stops post-Brexit the nation which voted overwhelmingly to permit will be worst affected by it.Unlike a second EU vote the second independence referendum will not be a choice between mere predicted scenarios. Instead it will determinewe wish to remain in a Union which has already changed dramatically.        name : ballot,target: ballot_,params:.push

title: artificial-intelligence-could-help-create-more-specific-alzheimers-treatment
story: Medics have devised a new algorithm that can automatically spot dferent patterns of progression in patients suffering from a range of dementias, including Alzheimerrsquos disease.The algorithm, called Subtype and Stage Inference ndash or SuStaIn, uses medical images to show doctors what stage the disease has reached and identy whether patients will respond better to certain treatments.Researchers said the algorithm was able to identy three separate subtypes of Alzheimerrsquos disease from MRI scans of people with dementia, and said this ldquosubtyping would be possible very early in the disease process.The ability to identy the subtypes early on in the disease process and using non-invasive MRI scanning means there is a better chance of identying the best treatment for iniduals, scientists said.ldquoOne key reason for the failure of drug trials in Alzheimerrsquos disease is the broad mixture of very dferent patients they test a treatment with a strong effect on a particular subgroup of patients may show no overall effect on the full population so fail the drug trial, said Professor Daniel Alexander at the UCL Centre for Medical Image Computing.ldquoThis new algorithm has the unique ability to reveal groups of patients with dferent iants of disease.Professor Jonathan Schott, from the UCL Institute of Neurology, said understanding how dferent diseases evolve over time is ldquocritical for the design of treatments and providing information to patients about their prognosis.ldquoThis is a major challenge for diseases that evolve over years,not decades, and where there may be substantial dferences in the underlying pathology, and pattern and rates of progression between patients, Professor Scott said.ldquoThis work shows that it is possible to tease out dferent disease patterns ndash some hitherto unknown ndash from single MRI scans taken from patients with a range of dferent dementias.The researchers are now looking for ways to apply the algorithm to other diseases, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.It is believed the algorithm could be used by the NHS within the next few years. The NHS was unable to confirm the report.

title: cate-blanchett-defends-straight-actors-playing-lgbt-characters
story: Hollywood has been criticised for giving LGBT roles to straight actors and, earlier this year, Scarlett Johansson dropped out of playing a transgender character following a backlash.But Blanchett, who played a lesbian in rsquos Carol, disagrees with the idea that a performer can only form a deep bond with a characterthey have shared experiences and believes it defies the point of acting.According to the Hollywood Reporter, she said: ldquoIt also speaks to something that Irsquom quite passionate about in storytelling generally, but in film specically, which is that film can be quite a literal medium.ldquoAnd I will fight to the death for the right to suspend disbelief and play roles beyond my experience. I think reality television and all that that entails had an extraordinary impact, a profound impact on the way we view the creation of character.ldquoI think it provides a lot of opportunity, but the downside of it is that we now, particularly in America, I think, we expect and only expect people to make a profound connection to a character when itrsquos close to their experience.Sir Ian McKellen is among those critical of Hollywoodrsquos attitude to gay actors.No openly gay man has ever won the Academy Award for best actor, while straight actors have taken home the prize for playing LGBT roles.Tom Hanks won it for Philadelphia, while Sean Penn scooped it for Milk.In total,  straight people have been Oscar-nominated for playing gay characters.

story: Oscar winning actor Eddie Redmayne has donated a signed copy of his original script from The Theory of Everything, the biopic of Professor Stephen Hawking, who lived with MND for most of his adult le.Eddie, who was awarded the Academy Award for Best Actor for his portrayal of Professor Hawking said of the donation: ldquoIt seemed a fitting tribute to the memory of Stephen, to donate my signed script from The Theory of Everything to Sue Ryder. The charity provides vital support to people living with MND and Im delighted that funds raised from my donation will help to support people living with this and other le-changing conditions. Model and fashion icon Kate Moss, who has donated a signed copy of her coffee-table tome Kate by Kate Moss to the shop added: ldquoI regularly donate to my local Sue Ryder shop in North London and Irsquom delighted to be supporting the charity.Actress Gillian Anderson, star of cult shows such as X-Files and The Fall has donated a pair of Charles David sandals to the auction.Gillian said: ldquoIrsquom delighted to be contributing to Sue Ryder and to be helping a cause which does so much for people living with le-changing conditions.Money raised from the auction will support the expansion of Dee View Court, a specialist neurological care centre, based in Kincorth, Aberdeen.The centre provides care for people aged  and over living with le changing neurological conditions such as brain injuries, Parkinsonrsquos and Huntingtonrsquos disease, stroke and motor neurone disease. Dee View Court is currently the only purpose-built specialist neurological centre in Scotland.The charity is planning to expand Sue Ryder Dee View Court so they can give more people a chance to get the most out of le by giving them the care they need and deserve.The charity needs to raise £. million to build the extension and provide much needed services for people with neurological conditions in Scotland.The auction is just one initiative that will raise vital funds that will contribute towards reaching the £. million fundraising target to realise the expansion of Dee View Court.To view the items visit www.givergy charity sue-ryder.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"CLANs Inverurie base at Burnside Court"  CLAN reading group comes to Inverurie viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: new club gets off the mark
story: The newly formed Hatton of Fintray Gardening Club met last weekend for the first time.Eight keen gardeners braved a damp and dreich morning to plant bulbs in the centre of the village.Club President and Fintray resident, Ian Thompson, said: “We set up the club formally about a month ago with the aim of looking after the village landscape and making Fintray an even more attractive place to live. “This was our first project and despite the quite dismal weather, we all had a very enjoyable morning.“And the rain took care of the watering too.”The idea of forming a gardening club in the village first stemmed from an initiative held in the spring to create a village orchard in the recreation area. The orchard launch took place in March with the support of Aberdeenshire Council and help from the children of Hatton of Fintray Primary School, under the expert eye of special guest Jim McColl of BBC show Beechgrove Garden. Ian added: “The orchard has been such a success that forming a gardening club was a natural progression.“We’re grateful to our Community Association for funding the club and to Aberdeenshire Council for the bulbs, and we’re looking forward to seeing the results of our morning’s work in the spring.” Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: popular pumpkin patch set to open
story: A north east mum is busy preparing to open her popular pumpkin patch in Udny this weekend.Jenny Fyall is the founder of Udny Pumpkins, a pick your own pumpkin patch located near Udny Green.   Some of the pumpkins at Udny Pumpkins Former Scotsman journalist Jenny started Udny Pumpkins last year as she explained: “This will be our second year.“My husband John and I moved up here after purchasing a property that we had our eyes on for a while.“We kept animals and I was keen on growing my own vegetables, but we had a couple of fields that we weren’t using.“One of my friends said her two boys really wanted to go pumpkin picking but I had to ask her what that was as I had never heard of it.”   Isabelle and Thomas feed the animals at Udny Pumpkins After carrying out a lot of research Jenny found a new use for her unused land.She said: “I found out pumpkin picking was big in America but the more I looked into it I just thought it sounded so fun and I was so enthusiastic about it, and it sounded like something I would really enjoy doing.“The next day I bought , pumpkin seeds and pots and it has gone from there.”Jenny admitted the first year was used as a trial run to seethe idea would be popular.“When we opened I was astonished by the response and by day two we had sold out,” she said.“It’s nice for young people, especially children who live in Aberdeen who maybe don’t have a garden, they can come along, get their hands dirty and learn about growing pumpkins.”Jenny added: “We have grown ten dferent ieties of pumpkins this year.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..!
